**Colombia** ([/kəˈlʌmbiə/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")
[_kə-**LUM** -biə_](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key
"Help:Pronunciation respelling key") or [/kəˈlɒmbiə/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English") [_kə-**LOM**
-biə_](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling
key"); Spanish: [[ko̞ˈlõ̞mbjä]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish "Help:IPA/Spanish")
([![About this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Es-colombia.ogg "About this sound")
[listen](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/de/Es-colombia.ogg "Es-
colombia.ogg"))), officially the **Republic of Colombia**
([Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language"): [![About this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Es-republica_de_colombia.ogg "About this
sound") [ _República de
Colombia_](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ed/Es-
republica_de_colombia.ogg "Es-republica de colombia.ogg")
([help](/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help "Wikipedia:Media
help")·[info](/wiki/File:Es-republica_de_colombia.ogg "File:Es-republica de
colombia.ogg"))),[Note 1] is a [sovereign state](/wiki/Sovereign_state
"Sovereign state") largely situated in the northwest of [South
America](/wiki/South_America "South America"), with
[territories](/wiki/Insular_region_of_Colombia "Insular region of Colombia")
in Central America. Colombia shares a border to the northwest with
[Panama](/wiki/Panama "Panama"), to the east with [Venezuela](/wiki/Venezuela
"Venezuela") and [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil "Brazil") and to the south with
[Ecuador](/wiki/Ecuador "Ecuador") and [Peru](/wiki/Peru "Peru").[11] It
shares its maritime limits with [Costa Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica "Costa Rica"),
[Nicaragua](/wiki/Nicaragua "Nicaragua"), [Honduras](/wiki/Honduras
"Honduras"), [Jamaica](/wiki/Jamaica "Jamaica"), [Haiti](/wiki/Haiti "Haiti")
and the [Dominican Republic](/wiki/Dominican_Republic "Dominican
Republic").[12] It is a [unitary](/wiki/Unitary_state "Unitary state"),
constitutional [republic](/wiki/Republic "Republic") comprising thirty-two
[departments](/wiki/Departments_of_Colombia "Departments of Colombia"). The
territory of what is now Colombia was originally inhabited by [indigenous
peoples](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia "Indigenous peoples in
Colombia"), including the [Muisca](/wiki/Muisca "Muisca"),
[Quimbaya](/wiki/Quimbaya_civilization "Quimbaya civilization") and the
[Tairona](/wiki/Tairona "Tairona").

The Spanish set foot on Colombian soil for the first time in 1499 and in the
first half of the 16th century initiated a period of [conquest and
colonization](/wiki/Spanish_conquest_of_the_Muisca "Spanish conquest of the
Muisca"), ultimately creating the [New Kingdom of
Granada](/wiki/New_Kingdom_of_Granada "New Kingdom of Granada"), with as
capital [Santafé de Bogotá](/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1 "Bogotá").
[Independence](/wiki/Spanish_American_wars_of_independence "Spanish American
wars of independence") from [Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain") was acquired in 1819,
but by 1830 the "[Gran Colombia](/wiki/Gran_Colombia "Gran Colombia")"
Federation was dissolved. What is now Colombia and Panama emerged as the
[Republic of New Granada](/wiki/Republic_of_New_Granada "Republic of New
Granada"). The new nation experimented with federalism as the [Granadine
Confederation](/wiki/Granadine_Confederation "Granadine Confederation")
(1858), and then the [United States of
Colombia](/wiki/United_States_of_Colombia "United States of Colombia") (1863),
before the Republic of Colombia was finally declared in 1886. [Panama
seceded](/wiki/Separation_of_Panama_from_Colombia "Separation of Panama from
Colombia") in 1903. Since the 1960s, the country has suffered from an
asymmetric low-intensity [armed
conflict](/wiki/Colombian_armed_conflict_\(1964%E2%80%93present\) "Colombian
armed conflict \(1964–present\)"), which escalated in the 1990s but then
decreased from 2005 onward.[13] Colombia is one of the most
[ethnically](/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_Colombia "Race and ethnicity in
Colombia") and [linguistically](/wiki/Languages_of_Colombia "Languages of
Colombia") diverse countries in the world, and thereby possesses a rich
[cultural heritage](/wiki/Cultural_heritage "Cultural heritage"). The urban
centres are mostly located in the highlands of the [Andes
mountains](/wiki/Andean_natural_region "Andean natural region").

Colombian territory also encompasses [Amazon
rainforest](/wiki/Amazon_natural_region "Amazon natural region"), [tropical
grassland](/wiki/Orinoqu%C3%ADa_natural_region "Orinoquía natural region") and
both [Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean_natural_region "Caribbean natural region")
and [Pacific](/wiki/Pacific/Choc%C3%B3_natural_region "Pacific/Chocó natural
region") coastlines. Ecologically, it is one of the world's 17 [megadiverse
countries](/wiki/Megadiverse_countries "Megadiverse countries"), and the most
densely [biodiverse](/wiki/Biodiversity_of_Colombia "Biodiversity of
Colombia") of these per square kilometer.[14] Colombia is a [middle
power](/wiki/Middle_power "Middle power") and a [regional
actor](/wiki/Regional_power "Regional power") with the fourth-largest economy
in Latin America,[4] is part of the [CIVETS](/wiki/CIVETS "CIVETS") group of
six leading [emerging markets](/wiki/Emerging_markets "Emerging markets") and
is a member of the [UN](/wiki/UN "UN"), the [WTO](/wiki/WTO "WTO"), the
[OAS](/wiki/Organization_of_American_States "Organization of American
States"), the [Pacific Alliance](/wiki/Pacific_Alliance "Pacific Alliance"),
and other international organizations.[15] Colombia has a diversified economy
with macroeconomic stability and favorable growth prospects in the long
run.[16][17]

## Etymology

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Christopher_Columbus_Face.jpg/140px-
Christopher_Columbus_Face.jpg)](/wiki/File:Christopher_Columbus_Face.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Christopher_Columbus_Face.jpg "Enlarge")

_Colombia_ is named after [Christopher Columbus](/wiki/Christopher_Columbus
"Christopher Columbus")

The name "Colombia" is derived from the last name of [Christopher
Columbus](/wiki/Christopher_Columbus "Christopher Columbus")
([Italian](/wiki/Italian_language "Italian language"): _Cristoforo Colombo_ ,
[Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language"): _Cristóbal Colón_). It
was conceived by the Venezuelan revolutionary [Francisco de
Miranda](/wiki/Francisco_de_Miranda "Francisco de Miranda") as a reference to
all the New World, but especially to those portions under Spanish and
Portuguese rule. The name was later adopted by the [Republic of
Colombia](/wiki/Greater_Colombia "Greater Colombia") of 1819, formed from the
territories of the old [Viceroyalty of New
Granada](/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Granada "Viceroyalty of New Granada")
(modern-day Colombia, Panama, Venezuela, Ecuador, and northwest Brazil).[18]

When Venezuela, Ecuador and
[Cundinamarca](/wiki/Cundinamarca_Department_\(1820\) "Cundinamarca Department
\(1820\)") came to exist as independent states, the former [Department of
Cundinamarca](/wiki/Cundinamarca_Province "Cundinamarca Province") adopted the
name "[Republic of New Granada](/wiki/Republic_of_New_Granada "Republic of New
Granada")". New Granada officially changed its name in 1858 to the [Granadine
Confederation](/wiki/Granadine_Confederation "Granadine Confederation"). In
1863 the name was again changed, this time to [United States of
Colombia](/wiki/United_States_of_Colombia "United States of Colombia"), before
finally adopting its present name – the Republic of Colombia – in 1886.[18]

To refer to this country, the Colombian government uses the terms _Colombia_
and _República de Colombia_.

## History

Main articles: [History of Colombia](/wiki/History_of_Colombia "History of
Colombia") and [Timeline of Colombian
history](/wiki/Timeline_of_Colombian_history "Timeline of Colombian history")

### Pre-Columbian era

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Parque_Arqueol%C3%B3gico_de_San_Agust%C3%ADn_-
_tomb_of_a_deity_with_supporting_warriors.jpg/190px-
Parque_Arqueol%C3%B3gico_de_San_Agust%C3%ADn_-
_tomb_of_a_deity_with_supporting_warriors.jpg)](/wiki/File:Parque_Arqueol%C3%B3gico_de_San_Agust%C3%ADn_-
_tomb_of_a_deity_with_supporting_warriors.jpg)

[San Agustín Archaeological Park](/wiki/San_Agust%C3%ADn_Archaeological_Park
"San Agustín Archaeological Park")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Lost_City_Ruins.jpg/225px-
Lost_City_Ruins.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lost_City_Ruins.jpg)

[Ciudad Perdida](/wiki/Ciudad_Perdida "Ciudad Perdida") ("The Lost City")

Owing to its location, the present territory of Colombia was a corridor of
early human migration from [Mesoamerica](/wiki/Mesoamerica "Mesoamerica") and
the [Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean "Caribbean") to the [Andes](/wiki/Andes
"Andes") and [Amazon basin](/wiki/Amazon_basin "Amazon basin"). The oldest
archaeological finds are from the
[Pubenza](/w/index.php?title=Pubenza_archaeological_site&action=edit&redlink=1
"Pubenza archaeological site \(page does not exist\)") and [El
Totumo](/w/index.php?title=El_Totumo_archaeological_site&action=edit&redlink=1
"El Totumo archaeological site \(page does not exist\)") sites in the
Magdalena Valley 100 kilometres (62 mi) southwest of Bogotá.[19] These sites
date from the [Paleoindian](/wiki/Paleoindian "Paleoindian") period
(18,000–8000 BCE). At [Puerto
Hormiga](/wiki/Puerto_Hormiga_archaeological_site "Puerto Hormiga
archaeological site") and other sites, traces from the [Archaic
Period](/w/index.php?title=Archaic_period_in_South_America&action=edit&redlink=1
"Archaic period in South America \(page does not exist\)") (~8000–2000 BCE)
have been found. Vestiges indicate that there was also early occupation in the
regions of [El Abra](/wiki/El_Abra "El Abra") and
[Tequendama](/wiki/Tequendama_\(archaeological_site\) "Tequendama
\(archaeological site\)") in
[Cundinamarca](/wiki/Cundinamarca_Department_\(1820\) "Cundinamarca Department
\(1820\)"). The oldest pottery discovered in the Americas, found at [San
Jacinto](/w/index.php?title=San_Jacinto_archaeological_site&action=edit&redlink=1
"San Jacinto archaeological site \(page does not exist\)"), dates to 5000–4000
BCE.[20]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Muisca_raft_Legend_of_El_Dorado_Offerings_of_gold.jpg/220px-
Muisca_raft_Legend_of_El_Dorado_Offerings_of_gold.jpg)](/wiki/File:Muisca_raft_Legend_of_El_Dorado_Offerings_of_gold.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Muisca_raft_Legend_of_El_Dorado_Offerings_of_gold.jpg "Enlarge")

[Muisca raft](/wiki/Muisca_raft "Muisca raft"). The figure refers to the
ceremony of the legend of [El Dorado](/wiki/El_Dorado "El Dorado").

Indigenous people inhabited the territory that is now Colombia by 12,500 BCE.
Nomadic [hunter-gatherer](/wiki/Hunter-gatherer "Hunter-gatherer") tribes at
the [El Abra](/wiki/El_Abra "El Abra"), [Tibitó](/wiki/Tibit%C3%B3 "Tibitó")
and [Tequendama](/wiki/Tequendama "Tequendama") sites near present-day
[Bogotá](/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1 "Bogotá") traded with one another and with other
cultures from the [Magdalena River](/wiki/Magdalena_River "Magdalena River")
Valley.[21] Between 5000 and 1000 BCE, hunter-gatherer tribes transitioned to
agrarian societies; fixed settlements were established, and pottery appeared.
Beginning in the 1st millennium BCE, groups of [Amerindians](/wiki/Amerindian
"Amerindian") including the [Muisca](/wiki/Muisca "Muisca"),
[Quimbaya](/wiki/Quimbaya_civilization "Quimbaya civilization"), and
[Tairona](/wiki/Tairona "Tairona") developed the political system of
_[cacicazgos](/wiki/Cacicazgo "Cacicazgo")_ with a pyramidal structure of
power headed by [caciques](/wiki/Cacique_Nutibara_Bloc "Cacique Nutibara
Bloc"). The Muisca inhabited mainly the area of what is now the
[Departments](/wiki/Departments_of_Colombia "Departments of Colombia") of
[Boyacá](/wiki/Boyac%C3%A1_Department "Boyacá Department") and
[Cundinamarca](/wiki/Cundinamarca_Department "Cundinamarca Department") high
plateau (_[Altiplano Cundiboyacense](/wiki/Altiplano_Cundiboyacense "Altiplano
Cundiboyacense")_) where they formed the [Muisca
Confederation](/wiki/Muisca_Confederation "Muisca Confederation"). They farmed
maize, potato, quinoa and cotton, and traded gold,
[emeralds](/wiki/Colombian_emeralds "Colombian emeralds"), blankets, ceramic
handicrafts, coca and especially [rock salt](/wiki/Halite "Halite") with
neighboring nations. The Tairona inhabited northern Colombia in the isolated
mountain range of [Sierra Nevada de Santa
Marta](/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_de_Santa_Marta "Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta").[22]
The Quimbaya inhabited regions of the [Cauca River](/wiki/Cauca_River "Cauca
River") Valley between the [Western](/wiki/Cordillera_Occidental,_Colombia
"Cordillera Occidental, Colombia") and
[Central](/wiki/Cordillera_Central,_Colombia "Cordillera Central, Colombia")
Ranges of the Colombian Andes.[23] Most of the Amerindians practiced
agriculture and the social structure of each indigenous community was
different. Some groups of indigenous people such as the Caribs lived in a
state of permanent war, but others had less bellicose attitudes.[24] The Incas
expanded their [empire](/wiki/Inca_Empire "Inca Empire") onto the southwest
part of the country.[25]

### Spanish conquest

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/1500_map_by_Juan_de_la_Cosa.jpg/180px-1500_map_by_Juan_de_la_Cosa.jpg)](/wiki/File:1500_map_by_Juan_de_la_Cosa.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1500_map_by_Juan_de_la_Cosa.jpg "Enlarge")

[Map of Juan de la Cosa](/wiki/Map_of_Juan_de_la_Cosa "Map of Juan de la
Cosa"). It is the oldest known European cartographic representation of the New
World.

[Alonso de Ojeda](/wiki/Alonso_de_Ojeda "Alonso de Ojeda") (who had sailed
with Columbus) reached the [Guajira Peninsula](/wiki/Guajira_Peninsula
"Guajira Peninsula") in 1499.[26][27] Spanish explorers, led by [Rodrigo de
Bastidas](/wiki/Rodrigo_de_Bastidas "Rodrigo de Bastidas"), made the first
exploration of the [Caribbean coast](/wiki/Caribbean_Basin "Caribbean Basin")
in 1500.[28] [Christopher Columbus](/wiki/Christopher_Columbus "Christopher
Columbus") navigated near the Caribbean in 1502.[29] In 1508, [Vasco Núñez de
Balboa](/wiki/Vasco_N%C3%BA%C3%B1ez_de_Balboa "Vasco Núñez de Balboa")
accompanied an expedition to the territory through the region of [Gulf of
Urabá](/wiki/Gulf_of_Urab%C3%A1 "Gulf of Urabá") and they founded the town of
[Santa María la Antigua del
Darién](/wiki/Santa_Mar%C3%ADa_la_Antigua_del_Dari%C3%A9n "Santa María la
Antigua del Darién") in 1510, the first stable settlement on the continent.
[Note 2][30]

[Santa Marta](/wiki/Santa_Marta "Santa Marta") was founded in 1525,[31] and
[Cartagena](/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia "Cartagena, Colombia") in 1533.[32]
Spanish [conquistador](/wiki/Conquistador "Conquistador") [Gonzalo Jiménez de
Quesada](/wiki/Gonzalo_Jim%C3%A9nez_de_Quesada "Gonzalo Jiménez de Quesada")
led an expedition to the interior in April 1536, and christened the districts
through which he passed "[New Kingdom of Granada](/wiki/New_Kingdom_of_Granada
"New Kingdom of Granada")". In August 1538, he founded provisionally its
capital near the Muisca [cacicazgo](/wiki/Cacicazgo "Cacicazgo") of
[Bacatá](/wiki/Bacat%C3%A1 "Bacatá"), and named it "Santa Fe". The name soon
acquired a suffix and was called Santa Fe de Bogotá.[33][34] Two other notable
journeys by early conquistadors to the interior took place in the same period.
[Sebastián de Belalcázar](/wiki/Sebasti%C3%A1n_de_Belalc%C3%A1zar "Sebastián
de Belalcázar"), conqueror of [Quito](/wiki/Quito "Quito"), traveled north and
founded [Cali](/wiki/Cali "Cali"), in 1536, and [Popayán](/wiki/Popay%C3%A1n
"Popayán"), in 1537;[35] from 1536 to 1539, German conquistador [Nikolaus
Federmann](/wiki/Nikolaus_Federmann "Nikolaus Federmann") crossed the [Llanos
Orientales](/wiki/Orinoqu%C3%ADa_Natural_Region,_Colombia "Orinoquía Natural
Region, Colombia") and went over the [Cordillera
Oriental](/wiki/Cordillera_Oriental_\(Colombia\) "Cordillera Oriental
\(Colombia\)") in a search for [El Dorado](/wiki/El_Dorado "El Dorado"), the
"city of gold".[36][37] The legend and the gold would play a pivotal role in
luring the Spanish and other Europeans to New Granada during the 16th and 17th
centuries.[38]

The [conquistadors](/wiki/List_of_conquistadors_in_Colombia "List of
conquistadors in Colombia") made frequent alliances with the enemies of
different indigenous communities. [Indigenous allies](/wiki/Indian_auxiliaries
"Indian auxiliaries") were crucial to conquest, as well as to creating and
maintaining empire.[39] Indigenous peoples in New Granada experienced a
decline in population due to conquest as well as Eurasian diseases, such as
[smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox "Smallpox"), to which they had no immunity.[40][41]
With the risk that the land was deserted, the Spanish Crown sold properties to
all persons interested in colonise territories creating large farms and
possession of mines.[42][43][44]

In the 16th century, the [nautical science](/wiki/Nautical_science "Nautical
science") in [Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain") reached a great development thanks
to numerous scientific figures of the [Casa de
Contratación](/wiki/Casa_de_Contrataci%C3%B3n "Casa de Contratación") and
nautical science was an essential pillar of the [Iberian
expansion](/wiki/Iberian_ship_development,_1400%E2%80%931600 "Iberian ship
development, 1400–1600").[45]

### Colonial period

In 1542, the region of New Granada, along with all other Spanish possessions
in South America, became part of the [Viceroyalty of
Peru](/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_Peru "Viceroyalty of Peru"), with its capital at
[Lima](/wiki/Lima "Lima").[46] In 1547, New Granada became the [Captaincy-
General of New Granada](/w/index.php?title=Captaincy-
General_of_New_Granada&action=edit&redlink=1 "Captaincy-General of New Granada
\(page does not exist\)") within the viceroyalty.

In 1549, the [Royal Audiencia](/wiki/Real_Audiencia "Real Audiencia") was
created by a royal decree, and New Granada was ruled by the [Royal Audience of
Santa Fe de Bogotá](/wiki/Royal_Audience_of_Santa_Fe_de_Bogot%C3%A1 "Royal
Audience of Santa Fe de Bogotá"), which at that time comprised the provinces
of Santa Marta, Rio de San Juan, Popayán, Guayana and Cartagena.[47] But
important decisions were taken from the colony to Spain by the [Council of the
Indies](/wiki/Council_of_the_Indies "Council of the Indies").[48][49]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/7e/Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo%2C_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg/220px-
Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo%2C_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg)](/wiki/File:Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo,_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Defensa_de_Cartagena_de_Indias_por_la_escuadra_de_D._Blas_de_Lezo,_a%C3%B1o_1741.jpg
"Enlarge")

Attack of the British army on Cartagena de Indias. [The
battle](/wiki/Battle_of_Cartagena_de_Indias "Battle of Cartagena de Indias")
resulted in a major defeat for the British Navy and Army during the [War of
Jenkins' Ear](/wiki/War_of_Jenkins%27_Ear "War of Jenkins' Ear"), 1739–48.[50]

In the 16th century, Europeans began to bring
[slaves](/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade "Atlantic slave trade") from Africa. Spain
was the only European power that could not establish
[factories](/wiki/Factory_\(trading_post\) "Factory \(trading post\)") in
Africa to purchase slaves and therefore the Spanish empire relied on the
[asiento](/wiki/Asiento "Asiento") system, awarding merchants (mostly from
[Portugal](/wiki/Portuguese_Empire "Portuguese Empire"),
[France](/wiki/French_colonial_empire "French colonial empire"),
[England](/wiki/South_Sea_Company#Slave_trade_under_the_Asiento "South Sea
Company") and the [Dutch Empire](/wiki/Dutch_Empire "Dutch Empire")) the
license to trade enslaved people to their overseas territories.[51][52] Also
there were people who defended the human rights and freedoms of oppressed
peoples.[Note 3][Note 4] The indigenous peoples could not be enslaved because
they were legally [subjects](/wiki/Commoners "Commoners") of the Spanish
Crown[57] and to protect the indigenous peoples, several forms of land
ownership and regulation were established: _resguardos_ , _encomiendas_ and
_haciendas_.[42][43][44]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg/200px-
Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ilustraciones_Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis.jpg "Enlarge")

Many intellectual leaders of the independence process participated in the
[Royal Botanical Expedition to New
Granada](/wiki/Royal_Botanical_Expedition_to_New_Granada "Royal Botanical
Expedition to New Granada").

In 1717 the [Viceroyalty of New Granada](/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Granada
"Viceroyalty of New Granada") was originally created, and then it was
temporarily removed, to finally be reestablished in 1739. The Viceroyalty had
Santa Fé de Bogotá as its capital. This Viceroyalty included some other
provinces of northwestern South America which had previously been under the
jurisdiction of the [Viceroyalties of New Spain](/wiki/New_Spain "New Spain")
or [Peru](/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_Peru "Viceroyalty of Peru") and correspond
mainly to today's Venezuela, Ecuador and Panama. So, Bogotá became one of the
principal administrative centers of the Spanish possessions in the New World,
along with [Lima](/wiki/Lima "Lima") and [Mexico City](/wiki/Mexico_City
"Mexico City"), though it remained somewhat backward compared to those two
cities in several economic and logistical ways.[58][59]

After Great Britain declared war on Spain in 1739,
[Cartagena](/wiki/Battle_of_Cartagena_de_Indias "Battle of Cartagena de
Indias") quickly became the British forces' top target but an upset Spanish
victory during the [War of Jenkins' Ear](/wiki/War_of_Jenkins%27_Ear "War of
Jenkins' Ear"), a war with Great Britain for economic control of the
Caribbean, cemented Spanish dominance in the [Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean
"Caribbean") until the [Seven Years' War](/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War "Seven
Years' War").[50][60]

The 18th-century priest, botanist and mathematician [José Celestino
Mutis](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Celestino_Mutis "José Celestino Mutis") was delegated
by Viceroy [Antonio Caballero y
Góngora](/wiki/Antonio_Caballero_y_G%C3%B3ngora "Antonio Caballero y Góngora")
to conduct an inventory of the nature of the New Granada. Started in 1783,
this became known as the [Royal Botanical Expedition to New
Granada](/wiki/Royal_Botanical_Expedition_to_New_Granada "Royal Botanical
Expedition to New Granada") which classified plants, wildlife and founded the
first astronomical observatory in the city of Santa Fe de Bogotá.[61] In July
1801 the Prussian scientist [Alexander von
Humboldt](/wiki/Alexander_von_Humboldt "Alexander von Humboldt") reached Santa
Fe de Bogotá where he met with Mutis. In addition, historical figures in the
process of independence in New Granada emerged from the expedition as the
astronomer [Francisco José de Caldas](/wiki/Francisco_Jos%C3%A9_de_Caldas
"Francisco José de Caldas"), the scientist [Francisco Antonio
Zea](/wiki/Francisco_Antonio_Zea "Francisco Antonio Zea"), the zoologist
[Jorge Tadeo Lozano](/wiki/Jorge_Tadeo_Lozano "Jorge Tadeo Lozano") and the
painter [Salvador Rizo](/wiki/Salvador_Rizo "Salvador Rizo").[62][63]

### Independence

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg/220px-
Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg)](/wiki/File:Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Batalla_de_Boyaca_de_Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Battle of Boyacá](/wiki/Battle_of_Boyac%C3%A1 "Battle of Boyacá") was the
decisive battle which would ensure the success of the [liberation campaign of
New Granada](/wiki/Bol%C3%ADvar%27s_campaign_to_liberate_New_Granada
"Bolívar's campaign to liberate New Granada").

Since the beginning of the periods of conquest and colonization, there were
several rebel movements against Spanish rule, but most were either crushed or
remained too weak to change the overall situation. The last one that sought
outright [independence from Spain](/wiki/Colombian_Declaration_of_Independence
"Colombian Declaration of Independence") sprang up around 1810, following the
independence of [St. Domingue](/wiki/St._Domingue "St. Domingue") (present-day
Haiti) in 1804, which provided some support to an eventual leader of this
rebellion: [Simón Bolívar](/wiki/Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar "Simón Bolívar").
[Francisco de Paula Santander](/wiki/Francisco_de_Paula_Santander "Francisco
de Paula Santander") also would play a decisive role.[64][65][66]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/ProvinciaSocorro.jpg/150px-
ProvinciaSocorro.jpg)](/wiki/File:ProvinciaSocorro.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:ProvinciaSocorro.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Socorro Province](/wiki/Socorro_Province "Socorro Province") was the site
of the [genesis](/wiki/Revolt_of_the_Comuneros_\(New_Granada\) "Revolt of the
Comuneros \(New Granada\)") of the independence process.

A movement was initiated by [Antonio Nariño](/wiki/Antonio_Nari%C3%B1o
"Antonio Nariño"), who opposed Spanish centralism and led the opposition
against the [Viceroyalty](/wiki/Viceroyalty "Viceroyalty").[67]
[Cartagena](/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia "Cartagena, Colombia") became
independent in November 1811.[68] In 1811 the [United Provinces of New
Granada](/wiki/United_Provinces_of_New_Granada "United Provinces of New
Granada") were proclaimed, headed by [Camilo Torres
Tenorio](/wiki/Camilo_Torres_Tenorio "Camilo Torres Tenorio").[69][70] The
emergence of two distinct ideological currents among the
[patriots](/wiki/Patriot_\(Spanish_American_independence\) "Patriot \(Spanish
American independence\)") ([federalism](/wiki/Federalism "Federalism") and
[centralism](/wiki/Unitary_state "Unitary state")) gave rise to a period of
[instability](/wiki/Patria_Boba "Patria Boba").[71] Shortly after the
[Napoleonic Wars](/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars "Napoleonic Wars") ended, [Ferdinand
VII](/wiki/Ferdinand_VII "Ferdinand VII"), recently restored to the throne in
Spain, unexpectedly decided [to send military
forces](/wiki/Spanish_reconquest_of_New_Granada "Spanish reconquest of New
Granada") to retake most of northern South America. The viceroyalty was
restored under the command of [Juan Sámano](/wiki/Juan_S%C3%A1mano "Juan
Sámano"), whose regime punished those who participated in the patriotic
movements, ignoring the political nuances of the
[juntas](/wiki/Junta_\(Spanish_American_Independence\) "Junta \(Spanish
American Independence\)").[72] The retribution stoked renewed rebellion,
which, combined with a weakened Spain, made possible a successful rebellion
led by the Venezuelan-born [Simón
Bolívar](/wiki/Military_career_of_Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar "Military career of
Simón Bolívar"), who finally proclaimed
[independence](/wiki/Spanish_American_wars_of_independence "Spanish American
wars of independence") in 1819.[73][74] The [pro-Spanish
resistance](/wiki/Royalist_\(Spanish_American_Independence\) "Royalist
\(Spanish American Independence\)") was defeated in 1822 in the present
territory of Colombia and in 1823 in Venezuela.[75][76][77]

The territory of the Viceroyalty of New Granada became the [Republic of
Colombia](/wiki/Gran_Colombia "Gran Colombia"), organized as a [union of the
current territories](/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Gran_Colombia "Subdivisions of Gran
Colombia") of Colombia, Panama, Ecuador, Venezuela, parts of Guyana and Brazil
and north of [Marañón River](/wiki/Mara%C3%B1%C3%B3n_River "Marañón
River").[78] The [Congress of Cúcuta](/wiki/Congress_of_C%C3%BAcuta "Congress
of Cúcuta") in 1821 adopted a
[constitution](/wiki/Colombian_Constitution_of_1821 "Colombian Constitution of
1821") for the new Republic.[79][80] Simón Bolívar became the first [President
of Colombia](/wiki/President_of_Colombia "President of Colombia"), and
Francisco de Paula Santander was made [Vice
President](/wiki/Vice_President_of_Colombia "Vice President of Colombia").[81]
However, the new republic was unstable and three countries emerged from the
collapse of [Gran Colombia](/wiki/Gran_Colombia "Gran Colombia") in 1830 (New
Granada, Ecuador and Venezuela).[82][83]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif/220px-
Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif)](/wiki/File:Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Cambios_territoriales_de_Colombia.gif "Enlarge")

Formation of the present Colombia since the [Viceroyalty of New
Granada](/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Granada "Viceroyalty of New Granada")'s
independence from the [Spanish Empire](/wiki/Spanish_Empire "Spanish Empire")

Colombia was the first [constitutional
government](/wiki/Constitutional_government "Constitutional government") in
South America,[84] and the [Liberal](/wiki/Colombian_Liberal_Party "Colombian
Liberal Party") and [Conservative](/wiki/Colombian_Conservative_Party
"Colombian Conservative Party") parties, founded in 1848 and 1849
respectively, are two of the oldest surviving [political
parties](/wiki/Political_parties "Political parties") in the Americas.[85]
[Slavery](/wiki/Slavery "Slavery") was abolished in the country in
1851.[86][87]

Internal political and territorial divisions led to the dissolution of [Gran
Colombia](/wiki/Gran_Colombia "Gran Colombia") in 1830.[82][83] The so-called
"[Department of Cundinamarca](/wiki/Cundinamarca_Province "Cundinamarca
Province")" adopted the name "[New Granada](/wiki/Republic_of_the_New_Granada
"Republic of the New Granada")", which it kept until 1858 when it became the
"Confederación Granadina" ([Granadine
Confederation](/wiki/Granadine_Confederation "Granadine Confederation")).
After a [two-year civil war](/wiki/Colombian_Civil_War_\(1860%E2%80%931862\)
"Colombian Civil War \(1860–1862\)") in 1863, the "[United States of
Colombia](/wiki/United_States_of_Colombia "United States of Colombia")" was
created, lasting until 1886, when the country finally became known as the
Republic of Colombia.[84][88] Internal divisions remained between the
bipartisan political forces, occasionally igniting very bloody civil wars, the
most significant being the [Thousand Days' War](/wiki/Thousand_Days%27_War
"Thousand Days' War") (1899–1902).[89]

### 20th century

The United States of America's intentions to influence the area (especially
the [Panama Canal](/wiki/Panama_Canal "Panama Canal") construction and
control) led to the [separation of the Department of
Panama](/wiki/Separation_of_Panama_from_Colombia "Separation of Panama from
Colombia") in 1903 and the establishment of it as a nation.[90] The United
States paid Colombia $25,000,000 in 1921, seven years after completion of the
canal, for redress of President [Roosevelt](/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt "Theodore
Roosevelt")'s role in the creation of Panama, and Colombia recognized Panama
under the terms of the [Thomson–Urrutia
Treaty](/wiki/Thomson%E2%80%93Urrutia_Treaty "Thomson–Urrutia Treaty").[91]
Colombia and Peru went to [war](/wiki/Leticia_Incident "Leticia Incident")
because of territory disputes far in the [Amazon basin](/wiki/Amazon_basin
"Amazon basin"). The war ended with a peace deal brokered by the [League of
Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations"). The League finally
awarded the disputed area to Colombia in June 1934.[92]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Bogotazo.jpg/220px-
Bogotazo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bogotazo.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bogotazo.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Bogotazo](/wiki/Bogotazo "Bogotazo") in 1948

Soon after, Colombia achieved some degree of political stability, which was
interrupted by a bloody conflict that took place between the late 1940s and
the early 1950s, a period known as _[La Violencia](/wiki/La_Violencia "La
Violencia")_ ("The Violence"). Its cause was mainly mounting tensions between
the two leading political parties, which subsequently ignited after the
assassination of the Liberal presidential candidate [Jorge Eliécer
Gaitán](/wiki/Jorge_Eli%C3%A9cer_Gait%C3%A1n "Jorge Eliécer Gaitán") on 9
April 1948.[93][94] The ensuing riots in Bogotá, known as [El
Bogotazo](/wiki/El_Bogotazo "El Bogotazo"), spread throughout the country and
claimed the lives of at least 180,000 Colombians.[95]

Colombia entered the [Korean War](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War") when
[Laureano Gómez](/wiki/Laureano_G%C3%B3mez "Laureano Gómez") was elected
president. It was the only Latin American country to join the war in a direct
military role as an ally of the United States. Particularly important was the
resistance of the Colombian troops at [Old Baldy](/wiki/Battle_of_Old_Baldy
"Battle of Old Baldy").[96]

The violence between the two political parties decreased first when [Gustavo
Rojas](/wiki/Gustavo_Rojas_Pinilla "Gustavo Rojas Pinilla") deposed the
[President](/wiki/Laureano_G%C3%B3mez "Laureano Gómez") of Colombia in a coup
d'état and negotiated with the guerrillas, and then under the [military
junta](/wiki/Colombian_Military_Junta "Colombian Military Junta") of General
[Gabriel París](/wiki/Gabriel_Par%C3%ADs "Gabriel París").[97][98]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-
_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg/220px-Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-
_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-
_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Centro_de_Memoria_Hist%C3%B3rica_-_Bogot%C3%A1.jpg "Enlarge")

The Axis of Peace and Memory: A "memorial" to the victims of the conflict

After Rojas' deposition, the Colombian Conservative Party and Colombian
Liberal Party agreed to create the [National
Front](/wiki/National_Front_\(Colombia\) "National Front \(Colombia\)"), a
coalition which would jointly govern the country. Under the deal, the
presidency would alternate between conservatives and liberals every 4 years
for 16 years; the two parties would have parity in all other elective
offices.[99] The National Front ended "La Violencia", and National Front
administrations attempted to institute far-reaching social and economic
reforms in cooperation with the [Alliance for
Progress](/wiki/Alliance_for_Progress "Alliance for Progress").[100][101]
Despite the progress in certain sectors, many social and political problems
continued, and guerrilla groups were formally created such as the
[FARC](/wiki/Revolutionary_Armed_Forces_of_Colombia "Revolutionary Armed
Forces of Colombia"), the [ELN](/wiki/National_Liberation_Army_\(Colombia\)
"National Liberation Army \(Colombia\)") and the
[M-19](/wiki/19th_of_April_Movement "19th of April Movement") to fight the
government and political apparatus.[102]

Since the 1960s, the country has suffered from an
[asymmetric](/wiki/Asymmetric_warfare "Asymmetric warfare") [low-
intensity](/wiki/Low_intensity_conflict "Low intensity conflict") [armed
conflict](/wiki/Colombian_armed_conflict_\(1964%E2%80%93present\) "Colombian
armed conflict \(1964–present\)") between [government
forces](/wiki/Military_Forces_of_Colombia "Military Forces of Colombia"),
[leftist guerrilla groups](/wiki/Guerrilla_movements_in_Colombia "Guerrilla
movements in Colombia") and [right wing
paramilitaries](/wiki/Paramilitarism_in_Colombia "Paramilitarism in
Colombia").[103] The conflict escalated in the 1990s,[104] mainly in remote
rural areas.[105] Since the beginning of the armed conflict, [human rights
defenders](/wiki/Human_rights_defenders "Human rights defenders") have fought
for the respect for [human rights](/wiki/Human_rights "Human rights"), despite
staggering opposition.[Note 5][Note 6] Several guerrillas' organizations
decided to demobilize after peace negotiations in 1989–1994.[13]

The United States has been heavily involved in the conflict since its
beginnings, when in the early 1960s the [U.S.
government](/wiki/U.S._government "U.S. government") encouraged the Colombian
military to attack leftist militias in rural Colombia. This was part of the
U.S. fight against communism. [Mercenaries](/wiki/Mercenarie "Mercenarie") and
multinational corporations such as [Chiquita Brands
International](/wiki/Chiquita_Brands_International "Chiquita Brands
International") are some of the international actors that have contributed to
the violence of the conflict.[103][13][109]

On 4 July 1991, a new [Constitution](/wiki/Colombian_Constitution_of_1991
"Colombian Constitution of 1991") was promulgated. The changes generated by
the new constitution are viewed as positive by Colombian society.[110][111]

### 21st century

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Jefa_de_Estado_participa_en_ceremonia_de_la_Firma_de_la_Paz_entre_el_Gobierno_de_Colombia_y_las_FARC_E.P._%2829953487045%29.jpg/235px-
Jefa_de_Estado_participa_en_ceremonia_de_la_Firma_de_la_Paz_entre_el_Gobierno_de_Colombia_y_las_FARC_E.P._%2829953487045%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jefa_de_Estado_participa_en_ceremonia_de_la_Firma_de_la_Paz_entre_el_Gobierno_de_Colombia_y_las_FARC_E.P._\(29953487045\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jefa_de_Estado_participa_en_ceremonia_de_la_Firma_de_la_Paz_entre_el_Gobierno_de_Colombia_y_las_FARC_E.P._\(29953487045\).jpg
"Enlarge")

President [Juan Manuel Santos](/wiki/Juan_Manuel_Santos "Juan Manuel Santos")
signed a [peace accord](/wiki/Colombian_peace_process "Colombian peace
process").

The administration of President [Álvaro Uribe](/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Uribe "Álvaro
Uribe") (2002–10), adopted the [democratic security
policy](/wiki/Democratic_security_policy "Democratic security policy") which
included an integrated [counter-terrorism](/wiki/Counter-terrorism "Counter-
terrorism") and [counter-insurgency](/wiki/Counter-insurgency "Counter-
insurgency") campaign.[112] The Government economic plan also promoted
confidence in investors.[113] As part of a controversial peace process the
[AUC](/wiki/United_Self-Defense_Forces_of_Colombia "United Self-Defense Forces
of Colombia") (right-wing paramilitaries) as a formal organization had ceased
to function.[114] In February 2008, millions of Colombians demonstrated
against FARC and other outlawed groups.[115]

After peace negotiations in [Cuba](/wiki/Cuba "Cuba"), the [Colombian
government](/wiki/Government_of_Colombia "Government of Colombia") of
President [Juan Manuel Santos](/wiki/Juan_Manuel_Santos "Juan Manuel Santos")
and [guerrilla](/wiki/Guerrilla "Guerrilla") of FARC-EP announced a final
agreement to end the conflict.[116] However, a
[referendum](/wiki/Colombian_peace_agreement_referendum,_2016 "Colombian peace
agreement referendum, 2016") to ratify the deal was unsuccessful.[117][118]
Afterward, the Colombian government and the FARC signed a revised [peace
deal](/wiki/Colombian_peace_process "Colombian peace process") in November
2016,[119] which the [Colombian congress](/wiki/Colombian_congress "Colombian
congress") approved.[120] In 2016, President Santos was awarded the [Nobel
Peace Prize](/wiki/2016_Nobel_Peace_Prize "2016 Nobel Peace Prize").[121] The
Government began a process of attention and comprehensive reparation for
victims of conflict.[122][123] Colombia shows modest progress in the struggle
to defend human rights, as expressed by [HRW](/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch "Human
Rights Watch").[124] A Special Jurisdiction for Peace has been created to
investigate, clarify, prosecute and punish serious human rights violations and
grave breaches of [international humanitarian
law](/wiki/International_humanitarian_law "International humanitarian law")
which occurred during the armed conflict and to satisfy victims' right to
[justice](/wiki/Justice "Justice").[125] During his visit to Colombia, [Pope
Francis](/wiki/Pope_Francis "Pope Francis") paid tribute to the victims of the
conflict.[126]

In terms of international relations, Colombia and Venezuela have agreed to
restore [diplomatic
relations](/wiki/2010_Colombia%E2%80%93Venezuela_diplomatic_crisis "2010
Colombia–Venezuela diplomatic crisis").[127] Colombian authorities due to the
situation in Venezuela are preparing an emergency contingency plan.[128] Latin
America, with a long memory of [U.S.
interventions](/wiki/List_of_authoritarian_regimes_supported_by_the_United_States
"List of authoritarian regimes supported by the United States") such as the
infamous [Operation Condor](/wiki/Operation_Condor "Operation Condor"),
rejects US military threat against Venezuela.[129] Colombia's Foreign Ministry
said that all efforts to resolve [Venezuela's
crisis](/wiki/Crisis_in_Venezuela_\(2012%E2%80%93present\) "Crisis in
Venezuela \(2012–present\)") should be peaceful and respect its
sovereignty.[130] Colombia proposed the idea of the [Sustainable Development
Goals](/wiki/Sustainable_Development_Goals "Sustainable Development Goals")
and a final document was adopted by the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations
"United Nations").[131] Colombia with a very clean electricity generation
matrix reaffirms its support for the [Paris Climate
Agreement](/wiki/Paris_Climate_Agreement "Paris Climate Agreement").[132]

## Geography

Main article: [Geography of Colombia](/wiki/Geography_of_Colombia "Geography
of Colombia")

See also: [Geology of Colombia](/wiki/Geology_of_Colombia "Geology of
Colombia"), [List of national parks of
Colombia](/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Colombia "List of national parks of
Colombia"), and [List of rivers in Colombia](/wiki/List_of_rivers_in_Colombia
"List of rivers in Colombia")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Mapa_de_Colombia_%28relieve%29.svg/235px-
Mapa_de_Colombia_%28relieve%29.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Mapa_de_Colombia_\(relieve\).svg)

[](/wiki/File:Mapa_de_Colombia_\(relieve\).svg "Enlarge")

Relief map

The geography of Colombia is characterized by its six main [natural
regions](/wiki/Natural_regions_of_Colombia "Natural regions of Colombia") that
present their own unique characteristics, from the [Andes mountain
range](/wiki/Andes "Andes") region shared with Ecuador and Venezuela; the
[Pacific coastal region](/wiki/Pacific_Coast "Pacific Coast") shared with
Panama and Ecuador; the Caribbean coastal region shared with Venezuela and
Panama; the _[Llanos](/wiki/Los_Llanos,_Venezuela "Los Llanos, Venezuela")_
(plains) shared with Venezuela; the [Amazon
Rainforest](/wiki/Amazon_Rainforest "Amazon Rainforest") region shared with
Venezuela, Brazil, Peru and Ecuador; to the [insular
area](/wiki/Insular_Region_\(Colombia\) "Insular Region \(Colombia\)"),
comprising islands in both the Atlantic and Pacific oceans.[133]

Colombia is bordered to the northwest by [Panama](/wiki/Panama "Panama"); to
the east by [Venezuela](/wiki/Venezuela "Venezuela") and [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil
"Brazil"); to the south by [Ecuador](/wiki/Ecuador "Ecuador") and
[Peru](/wiki/Peru "Peru");[11] it established its maritime boundaries with
neighboring countries through seven agreements on the Caribbean Sea and three
on the Pacific Ocean.[12] It lies between latitudes
[12°N](/wiki/12th_parallel_north "12th parallel north") and
[4°S](/wiki/4th_parallel_south "4th parallel south"), and longitudes
[67°](/wiki/67th_meridian_west "67th meridian west") and
[79°W](/wiki/79th_meridian_west "79th meridian west").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Colombia_koppen.svg/220px-
Colombia_koppen.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Colombia_koppen.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Colombia_koppen.svg "Enlarge")

Colombia map of [Köppen climate
classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate
classification")

Part of the [Ring of Fire](/wiki/Pacific_Ring_of_Fire "Pacific Ring of Fire"),
a region of the world subject to earthquakes and [volcanic
eruptions](/wiki/Volcano "Volcano"),[134] in the interior of Colombia the
Andes are the prevailing geographical feature. Most of Colombia's population
centers are located in these interior highlands. Beyond the [Colombian
Massif](/wiki/Colombian_Massif "Colombian Massif") (in the south-western
departments of [Cauca](/wiki/Cauca_Department "Cauca Department") and
[Nariño](/wiki/Nari%C3%B1o_Department "Nariño Department")) these are divided
into three branches known as _cordilleras_ (mountain ranges): the [Cordillera
Occidental](/wiki/Cordillera_Occidental_\(Colombia\) "Cordillera Occidental
\(Colombia\)"), running adjacent to the Pacific coast and including the city
of [Cali](/wiki/Santiago_de_Cali "Santiago de Cali"); the [Cordillera
Central](/wiki/Cordillera_Central_\(Colombia\) "Cordillera Central
\(Colombia\)"), running between the [Cauca](/wiki/Cauca_River "Cauca River")
and [Magdalena River](/wiki/Magdalena_River "Magdalena River") valleys (to the
west and east respectively) and including the cities of
[Medellín](/wiki/Medell%C3%ADn "Medellín"), [Manizales](/wiki/Manizales
"Manizales"), [Pereira](/wiki/Pereira,_Colombia "Pereira, Colombia") and
[Armenia](/wiki/Armenia,_Quind%C3%ADo "Armenia, Quindío"); and the [Cordillera
Oriental](/wiki/Cordillera_Oriental_\(Colombia\) "Cordillera Oriental
\(Colombia\)"), extending north east to the [Guajira
Peninsula](/wiki/Guajira_Peninsula "Guajira Peninsula") and including Bogotá,
[Bucaramanga](/wiki/Bucaramanga "Bucaramanga") and [Cúcuta](/wiki/C%C3%BAcuta
"Cúcuta").[133][135][136]

Peaks in the Cordillera Occidental exceed 4,700 m (15,420 ft), and in the
Cordillera Central and Cordillera Oriental they reach 5,000 m (16,404 ft). At
2,600 m (8,530 ft), Bogotá is the highest city of its size in the world.[133]

East of the Andes lies the [savanna](/wiki/Savanna "Savanna") of the
_[Llanos](/wiki/Los_Llanos,_Venezuela "Los Llanos, Venezuela")_ , part of the
[Orinoco River basin](/wiki/Orinoco "Orinoco"), and, in the far south east,
the [jungle](/wiki/Jungle "Jungle") of the [Amazon
rainforest](/wiki/Amazon_rainforest "Amazon rainforest"). Together these
lowlands comprise over half Colombia's territory, but they contain less than
6% of the population. To the north the [Caribbean
coast](/wiki/Caribbean_Region_of_Colombia "Caribbean Region of Colombia"),
home to 21.9% of the population and the location of the major port cities of
[Barranquilla](/wiki/Barranquilla "Barranquilla") and
[Cartagena](/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia "Cartagena, Colombia"), generally
consists of low-lying plains, but it also contains the [Sierra Nevada de Santa
Marta](/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_de_Santa_Marta "Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta")
mountain range, which includes the country's tallest peaks ([Pico Cristóbal
Colón](/wiki/Pico_Crist%C3%B3bal_Col%C3%B3n "Pico Cristóbal Colón") and [Pico
Simón Bolívar](/wiki/Pico_Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar "Pico Simón Bolívar")), and
the [La Guajira Desert](/wiki/La_Guajira_Desert "La Guajira Desert"). By
contrast the narrow and discontinuous [Pacific coastal
lowlands](/wiki/Pacific_Region_of_Colombia "Pacific Region of Colombia"),
backed by the [Serranía de Baudó](/wiki/Baud%C3%B3_Mountains "Baudó
Mountains") mountains, are sparsely populated and covered in dense vegetation.
The principal Pacific port is [Buenaventura](/wiki/Buenaventura,_Colombia
"Buenaventura, Colombia").[133][135][136]

The main rivers of Colombia are [Magdalena](/wiki/Magdalena_River "Magdalena
River"), [Cauca](/wiki/Cauca_River "Cauca River"),
[Guaviare](/wiki/Guaviare_River "Guaviare River"), [Atrato](/wiki/Atrato_River
"Atrato River"), [Meta](/wiki/Meta_River "Meta River"),
[Putumayo](/wiki/Putumayo_River "Putumayo River") and
[Caquetá](/wiki/Caquet%C3%A1_River "Caquetá River"). Colombia has four main
drainage systems: the Pacific drain, the Caribbean drain, the Orinoco Basin
and the Amazon Basin. The [Orinoco](/wiki/Orinoco "Orinoco") and
[Amazon](/wiki/Amazon_River "Amazon River") Rivers mark limits with Colombia
to Venezuela and Peru respectively.[137]

Protected areas and the "National Park System" cover an area of about
14,268,224 hectares (142,682.24 km2) and account for 12.77% of the Colombian
territory.[138] Compared to neighboring countries, rates of deforestation in
Colombia are still relatively low.[139] Colombia is the sixth country in the
world by magnitude of total renewable freshwater supply, and still has large
reserves of freshwater.[140]

### Climate

Main article: [Climate of Colombia](/wiki/Climate_of_Colombia "Climate of
Colombia")

The climate of Colombia is characterized for being [tropical](/wiki/Tropical
"Tropical") presenting variations within [six natural
regions](/wiki/Natural_regions_of_Colombia "Natural regions of Colombia") and
depending on the altitude, temperature, [humidity](/wiki/Humidity "Humidity"),
[winds](/wiki/Wind "Wind") and [rainfall](/wiki/Rainfall "Rainfall").[141] The
diversity of climate zones in Colombia is characterized for having [tropical
rainforests](/wiki/Tropical_rainforest "Tropical rainforest"),
[savannas](/wiki/Savanna "Savanna"), [steppes](/wiki/Steppe "Steppe"),
[deserts](/wiki/Desert "Desert") and mountain climate.

[Mountain climate](/wiki/Mountain_climate "Mountain climate") is one of the
unique features of the Andes and other high altitude reliefs where climate is
determined by elevation. Below 1,000 meters (3,281 ft) in elevation is the
[warm altitudinal zone](/wiki/Tierra_caliente "Tierra caliente"), where
[temperatures](/wiki/Temperature "Temperature") are above 24 °C (75.2 °F).
About 82.5% of the country's total area lies in the warm altitudinal zone. The
[temperate climate altitudinal zone](/wiki/Tierra_templada "Tierra templada")
located between 1,001 and 2,000 meters (3,284 and 6,562 ft) is characterized
for presenting an average temperature ranging between 17 and 24 °C (62.6 and
75.2 °F). The [cold climate](/wiki/Tierra_fr%C3%ADa "Tierra fría") is present
between 2,001 and 3,000 meters (6,565 and 9,843 ft) and the temperatures vary
between 12 and 17 °C (53.6 and 62.6 °F). Beyond the cold land lie the alpine
conditions of the forested zone and then the treeless grasslands of the
[páramos](/wiki/P%C3%A1ramo "Páramo"). Above 4,000 meters (13,123 ft), where
temperatures are below freezing, the climate is [glacial](/wiki/Tierra_helada
"Tierra helada"), a zone of permanent snow and ice.[141]

### Biodiversity

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/ChlorochrysaNitidissimaKeulemans.jpg/170px-
ChlorochrysaNitidissimaKeulemans.jpg)](/wiki/File:ChlorochrysaNitidissimaKeulemans.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:ChlorochrysaNitidissimaKeulemans.jpg "Enlarge")

_[Chlorochrysa nitidissima](/wiki/Chlorochrysa_nitidissima "Chlorochrysa
nitidissima")_. Colombia is home to more bird species than any other country
in the world.

Main article: [Biodiversity of Colombia](/wiki/Biodiversity_of_Colombia
"Biodiversity of Colombia")

See also: [Fauna of Colombia](/wiki/Fauna_of_Colombia "Fauna of Colombia") and
[Flora of Colombia](/wiki/Flora_of_Colombia "Flora of Colombia")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Cattleya_trianae_tipo_Baronessa.jpg/220px-
Cattleya_trianae_tipo_Baronessa.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cattleya_trianae_tipo_Baronessa.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cattleya_trianae_tipo_Baronessa.jpg "Enlarge")

The national flower of Colombia is the [orchid](/wiki/Orchid "Orchid")
_[Cattleya trianae](/wiki/Cattleya_trianae "Cattleya trianae")_ , which was
named after the Colombian botanist and physician [José Jerónimo
Triana](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Jer%C3%B3nimo_Triana "José Jerónimo Triana").[142]

Colombia is one of the [megadiverse countries](/wiki/Megadiverse_countries
"Megadiverse countries") in [biodiversity](/wiki/Biodiversity
"Biodiversity"),[143] ranking first in [bird
species](/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Colombia "List of birds of Colombia").[144] As
for plants, the country has between 40,000 and 45,000 plant
[species](/wiki/Species "Species"), equivalent to 10 or 20% of total global
species, which is even more remarkable given that Colombia is considered a
country of intermediate size.[145] Colombia is the second most biodiverse
country in the world, lagging only after Brazil which is approximately 7 times
bigger.[14]

Colombia is the country in the planet more characterized by a high
biodiversity, with the highest rate of species by area unit worldwide and it
has the largest number of [endemisms](/wiki/Endemism "Endemism") (species that
are not found naturally anywhere else) of any country. About 10% of the
species of the [Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth") live in Colombia, including over
1,900 species of bird, more than in Europe and North America combined,
Colombia has 10% of the world's [mammals](/wiki/List_of_mammals_of_Colombia
"List of mammals of Colombia") species, 14% of the [amphibian](/wiki/Amphibian
"Amphibian") species and 18% of the [bird](/wiki/Endemic_birds_of_Colombia
"Endemic birds of Colombia") species of the world.[146]

Colombia has about 2,000 species of [marine fish](/wiki/Marine_fish "Marine
fish") and is the second most diverse country in [freshwater
fish](/wiki/Freshwater_fish "Freshwater fish"). Colombia is the country with
more endemic species of [butterflies](/wiki/List_of_butterflies_of_Colombia
"List of butterflies of Colombia"), number 1 in terms of [orchid](/wiki/Orchid
"Orchid") species and approximately 7,000 species of [beetles](/wiki/Beetle
"Beetle"). Colombia is second in the number of amphibian species and is the
third most diverse country in [reptiles](/wiki/List_of_reptiles_of_Colombia
"List of reptiles of Colombia") and [palms](/wiki/Arecaceae "Arecaceae").
There are about 1,900 species of [mollusks](/wiki/Mollusk "Mollusk") and
according to estimates there are about 300,000 species of
[invertebrates](/wiki/Invertebrates "Invertebrates") in the country. In
Colombia there are 32 terrestrial [biomes](/wiki/Biomes "Biomes") and 314
types of [ecosystems](/wiki/Ecosystems "Ecosystems").[147][148]

## Government and politics

Main article: [Government of Colombia](/wiki/Government_of_Colombia
"Government of Colombia")

See also: [Colombian Constitution of
1991](/wiki/Colombian_Constitution_of_1991 "Colombian Constitution of 1991")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Lado_sur_Casa_de_Nari%C3%B1o.jpg/250px-
Lado_sur_Casa_de_Nari%C3%B1o.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lado_sur_Casa_de_Nari%C3%B1o.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lado_sur_Casa_de_Nari%C3%B1o.jpg "Enlarge")

[Casa de Nariño](/wiki/Casa_de_Nari%C3%B1o "Casa de Nariño") is the official
home and principal workplace of the [President of
Colombia](/wiki/President_of_Colombia "President of Colombia").

The government of Colombia takes place within the framework of a
[presidential](/wiki/Presidential_system "Presidential system") [participatory
democratic](/wiki/Participatory_democracy "Participatory democracy") republic
as established in the Constitution of 1991.[111] In accordance with the
principle of [separation of powers](/wiki/Separation_of_powers "Separation of
powers"), government is divided into three branches: the executive branch, the
legislative branch and the judicial branch.[149]

As the head of the executive branch, the [President of
Colombia](/wiki/President_of_Colombia "President of Colombia") serves as both
[head of state](/wiki/Head_of_state "Head of state") and [head of
government](/wiki/Head_of_government "Head of government"), followed by the
[Vice President](/wiki/Vice_President_of_Colombia "Vice President of
Colombia") and the [Council of
Ministers](/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_the_Republic_of_Colombia "Council of
Ministers of the Republic of Colombia"). The president is elected by popular
vote to serve four-year term (In 2015, Colombia's Congress approved the repeal
of a 2004 constitutional amendment that eliminated the one-term limit for
presidents).[150] At the provincial level executive power is vested in
[department governors](/wiki/List_of_Colombian_Department_Governors "List of
Colombian Department Governors"), [municipal
mayors](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Colombia "Municipalities of Colombia") and
local administrators for smaller administrative subdivisions, such as
_[corregimientos](/wiki/Corregimientos_of_Colombia "Corregimientos of
Colombia")_ or _comunas_.[151] All regional elections are held one year and
five months after the presidential election.[152][153]

The legislative branch of government is represented nationally by the
[Congress](/wiki/Congress_of_Colombia "Congress of Colombia"), a bicameral
institution comprising a 166-seat [Chamber of
Representatives](/wiki/Chamber_of_Representatives_of_Colombia "Chamber of
Representatives of Colombia") and a 102-seat [Senate](/wiki/Senate_of_Colombia
"Senate of Colombia").[154][155] The Senate is elected nationally and the
Chamber of Representatives is elected in electoral districts.[156] Members of
both houses are elected to serve four-year terms two months before the
president, also by popular vote.[157]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Nuevopalaciodejusticia.JPG/220px-
Nuevopalaciodejusticia.JPG)](/wiki/File:Nuevopalaciodejusticia.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Nuevopalaciodejusticia.JPG "Enlarge")

Colombia's Palace of Justice

The judicial branch is headed by [four high
courts](/wiki/Judiciary_of_Colombia "Judiciary of Colombia"),[158] consisting
of the [Supreme Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Justice_of_Colombia "Supreme
Court of Justice of Colombia") which deals with penal and civil matters, the
[Council of State](/wiki/Council_of_State_of_Colombia "Council of State of
Colombia"), which has special responsibility for [administrative
law](/wiki/Administrative_law "Administrative law") and also provides legal
advice to the executive, the [Constitutional
Court](/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Colombia "Constitutional Court of
Colombia"), responsible for assuring the integrity of the Colombian
constitution, and the [Superior Council of
Judicature](/wiki/Superior_Council_of_Judicature "Superior Council of
Judicature"), responsible for auditing the judicial branch.[159] Colombia
operates a system of [civil law](/wiki/Civil_law_\(legal_system\) "Civil law
\(legal system\)"), which since 2005 has been applied through an [adversarial
system](/wiki/Adversarial_system "Adversarial system").

Despite a number of controversies, the [democratic security
policy](/wiki/Democratic_security_policy "Democratic security policy") has
ensured that former President [Uribe](/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Uribe "Álvaro Uribe")
remained popular among Colombian people, with his approval rating peaking at
76%, according to a poll in 2009.[160] However, having served two terms, he
was constitutionally barred from seeking re-election in 2010.[161] In the run-
off elections on 20 June 2010 the former Minister of defense [Juan Manuel
Santos](/wiki/Juan_Manuel_Santos "Juan Manuel Santos") won with 69% of the
vote against the second most popular candidate, [Antanas
Mockus](/wiki/Antanas_Mockus "Antanas Mockus"). A second round was required
since no candidate received over the 50% winning threshold of votes.[162]
Santos won nearly 51% of the vote in second-round elections on 15 June 2014,
beating right-wing rival [Óscar Iván
Zuluaga](/wiki/%C3%93scar_Iv%C3%A1n_Zuluaga "Óscar Iván Zuluaga"), who won
45%. His term as Colombia's president runs for four years beginning 7 August
2014.[163]

### Foreign affairs

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/VI_Cumbre_de_la_Alianza_del_Pac%C3%ADfico.jpg/185px-
VI_Cumbre_de_la_Alianza_del_Pac%C3%ADfico.jpg)](/wiki/File:VI_Cumbre_de_la_Alianza_del_Pac%C3%ADfico.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:VI_Cumbre_de_la_Alianza_del_Pac%C3%ADfico.jpg "Enlarge")

The VI Summit of the [Pacific Alliance](/wiki/Pacific_Alliance "Pacific
Alliance"): President of Colombia, [Juan Manuel
Santos](/wiki/Juan_Manuel_Santos "Juan Manuel Santos") is second from the
left.

Main article: [Foreign relations of
Colombia](/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Colombia "Foreign relations of Colombia")

See also: [Diplomatic missions of
Colombia](/wiki/Diplomatic_missions_of_Colombia "Diplomatic missions of
Colombia")

The foreign affairs of Colombia are headed by the President, as head of state,
and managed by the [Minister of Foreign
Affairs](/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_\(Colombia\) "Ministry of Foreign
Affairs \(Colombia\)").[164] Colombia has diplomatic missions in all
continents.[165]

Colombia was one of the 4 founding members of the [Pacific
Alliance](/wiki/Pacific_Alliance "Pacific Alliance"), which is a political,
economic and co-operative integration mechanism that promotes the free
circulation of goods, services, capital and persons between the members, as
well as a common stock exchange and joint embassies in several countries.[166]
Colombia is also a member of the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United
Nations"), the [World Trade Organization](/wiki/World_Trade_Organization
"World Trade Organization"), the [Organization of American
States](/wiki/Organization_of_American_States "Organization of American
States"), the [Organization of Ibero-American
States](/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States "Organization of Ibero-
American States"), the [Union of South American
Nations](/wiki/Union_of_South_American_Nations "Union of South American
Nations") and the [Andean Community of
Nations](/wiki/Andean_Community_of_Nations "Andean Community of
Nations").[167][168][169][170] Colombia is a global partner of
[NATO](/wiki/NATO "NATO").[171] Colombia is currently in the accession process
with the [OECD](/wiki/OECD "OECD").[172]

### Military

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Colombian_Air_Force_Sikorsky_UH-60L_Arp%C3%ADa_III_%28S-70A-41%29_Ram%C3%ADrez-1.jpg/220px-
Colombian_Air_Force_Sikorsky_UH-60L_Arp%C3%ADa_III_%28S-70A-41%29_Ram%C3%ADrez-1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Colombian_Air_Force_Sikorsky_UH-60L_Arp%C3%ADa_III_\(S-70A-41\)_Ram%C3%ADrez-1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Colombian_Air_Force_Sikorsky_UH-60L_Arp%C3%ADa_III_\(S-70A-41\)_Ram%C3%ADrez-1.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Arpía III](/wiki/Sikorsky_UH-60_Black_Hawk "Sikorsky UH-60 Black Hawk") of
the [Colombian Air Force](/wiki/Colombian_Air_Force "Colombian Air Force")

Main article: [Military of Colombia](/wiki/Military_of_Colombia "Military of
Colombia")

The executive branch of government is responsible for managing the defense of
Colombia, with the President [commander-in-chief](/wiki/Commander-in-chief
"Commander-in-chief") of the armed forces. The [Ministry of
Defence](/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Defence_\(Colombia\) "Ministry of National
Defence \(Colombia\)") exercises day-to-day control of the
[military](/wiki/Military_of_Colombia "Military of Colombia") and the
[Colombian National Police](/wiki/Colombian_National_Police "Colombian
National Police"). Colombia has 455,461 active military personnel.[173] And in
2016 3.4% of the country's GDP went towards military expenditure, placing it
24th in the world. Colombia's armed forces are the largest in Latin America,
and it is the second largest spender on its military after Brazil.[174][175]

The Colombian military is divided into three branches: the [National Army of
Colombia](/wiki/National_Army_of_Colombia "National Army of Colombia"); the
[Colombian Air Force](/wiki/Colombian_Air_Force "Colombian Air Force"); and
the [Colombian Navy](/wiki/Colombian_Navy "Colombian Navy"). The National
Police functions as a [gendarmerie](/wiki/Gendarmerie "Gendarmerie"),
operating independently from the military as the law enforcement agency for
the entire country. Each of these operates with their own intelligence
apparatus separate from the [National Intelligence
Directorate](/wiki/National_Intelligence_Directorate_\(Colombia\) "National
Intelligence Directorate \(Colombia\)") (DNI, in Spanish).[176]

The National Army is formed by divisions, brigades, special brigades and
special units;[177] the Colombian Navy by the [Naval
Infantry](/wiki/Colombian_Naval_Infantry "Colombian Naval Infantry"), the
Naval Force of the Caribbean, the Naval Force of the Pacific, the Naval Force
of the South, the Naval Force of the East, Colombia Coast Guards, Naval
Aviation and the Specific Command of San Andres y Providencia;[178] and the
Air Force by 15 air units.[179] The National Police has a presence in all
municipalities.

### Administrative divisions

Main articles: [Departments of Colombia](/wiki/Departments_of_Colombia
"Departments of Colombia") and [Municipalities of
Colombia](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Colombia "Municipalities of Colombia")

See also: [List of cities in Colombia](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Colombia "List
of cities in Colombia") and [Corregimientos of
Colombia](/wiki/Corregimientos_of_Colombia "Corregimientos of Colombia")

Colombia is divided into 32 [departments](/wiki/Departments_of_Colombia
"Departments of Colombia") and one [capital district](/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1
"Bogotá"), which is treated as a department (Bogotá also serves as the capital
of the [department of Cundinamarca](/wiki/Cundinamarca_Department
"Cundinamarca Department")). Departments are subdivided into
[municipalities](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Colombia "Municipalities of
Colombia"), each of which is assigned a municipal seat, and municipalities are
in turn subdivided into _[corregimientos](/wiki/Corregimientos_of_Colombia
"Corregimientos of Colombia")_ in rural areas and into
_[comunas](/w/index.php?title=Comunas_of_Colombia&action=edit&redlink=1
"Comunas of Colombia \(page does not exist\)")_ in urban areas. Each
department has a local government with a governor and assembly directly
elected to four-year terms, and each municipality is headed by a mayor and
council. There is a popularly elected local administrative board in each of
the _corregimientos_ or _comunas_.[180][181][182][183]

In addition to the capital four other cities have been designated
[districts](/wiki/Districts_of_Colombia "Districts of Colombia") (in effect
special municipalities), on the basis of special distinguishing features.
These are [Barranquilla](/wiki/Barranquilla "Barranquilla"),
[Cartagena](/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia "Cartagena, Colombia"), [Santa
Marta](/wiki/Santa_Marta "Santa Marta") and
[Buenaventura](/wiki/Buenaventura,_Colombia "Buenaventura, Colombia"). Some
departments have local administrative subdivisions, where towns have a large
concentration of population and municipalities are near each other (for
example in Antioquia and Cundinamarca). Where departments have a low
population (for example Amazonas, Vaupés and Vichada), special administrative
divisions are employed, such as "department _corregimientos_ ", which are a
hybrid of a municipality and a _corregimiento_.[180][181]
