## Economy

Main article: [Economy of Colombia](/wiki/Economy_of_Colombia "Economy of
Colombia")

See also: [Agriculture in Colombia](/wiki/Agriculture_in_Colombia "Agriculture
in Colombia") and [Industry of Colombia](/wiki/Industry_of_Colombia "Industry
of Colombia")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Colombia%27s_gross_domestic_product_by_sector_%282%29.png/400px-
Colombia%27s_gross_domestic_product_by_sector_%282%29.png)](/wiki/File:Colombia%27s_gross_domestic_product_by_sector_\(2\).png)

[](/wiki/File:Colombia%27s_gross_domestic_product_by_sector_\(2\).png
"Enlarge")

Colombia's gross domestic product by sector for the second half of the year
2015

Historically an agrarian economy, Colombia urbanised rapidly in the 20th
century, by the end of which just 15.8% of the workforce were employed in
agriculture, generating just 6.8% of GDP; 19.6% of the workforce were employed
in industry and 64.6% in services, responsible for 34.0% and 59.2% of GDP
respectively.[184][185] The country's [economic
production](/wiki/Economic_production "Economic production") is dominated by
its strong [domestic demand](/wiki/Domestic_demand "Domestic demand").
[Consumption expenditure](/wiki/Consumer_spending "Consumer spending") by
households is the largest component of GDP.[186][16][187]

Colombia's [market economy](/wiki/Market_economy "Market economy") grew
steadily in the latter part of the 20th century, with gross domestic product
(GDP) increasing at an average rate of over 4% per year between 1970 and 1998.
The country suffered a [recession](/wiki/Recession "Recession") in 1999 (the
first full year of negative growth since the [Great
Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression "Great Depression")), and the recovery from
that recession was long and painful. However, in recent years growth has been
impressive, reaching 6.9% in 2007, one of the [highest rates of
growth](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_\(real\)_growth_rate "List of countries
by GDP \(real\) growth rate") in Latin America.[188] According to
[International Monetary Fund](/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund "International
Monetary Fund") estimates, in 2012 Colombia's GDP (PPP) was US$500 billion
([28th in the world](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_\(PPP\) "List of countries
by GDP \(PPP\)") and third in South America).

Total [government expenditures](/wiki/Government_expenditures "Government
expenditures") account for 28.7 percent of the domestic economy. [Public
debt](/wiki/Public_debt "Public debt") equals 41 percent of gross domestic
product. A strong fiscal climate was reaffirmed by a boost in [bond
ratings](/wiki/Bond_ratings "Bond ratings").[189][190][191] Annual
[inflation](/wiki/Inflation "Inflation") closed 2016 at 5.75% YoY (vs. 6.77%
YoY in 2015).[192] The average national [unemployment
rate](/wiki/Unemployment_rate "Unemployment rate") in 2016 was 9.2%,[193]
although the informality is the biggest problem facing the [labour
market](/wiki/Labour_market "Labour market") (the income of formal workers
climbed 24.8% in 5 years while labor incomes of informal workers rose only
9%).[194] Colombia has [Free trade Zone](/wiki/Free_trade_Zone "Free trade
Zone") (FTZ),[195] such as Zona Franca del Pacifico, located in the Valle del
Cauca, one of the most striking areas for foreign investment.[196]

The [financial sector](/wiki/Financial_sector "Financial sector") has grown
favorably due to good liquidity in the economy, the growth of credit and the
positive performance of the Colombian economy.[17][197][198] The [Colombian
Stock Exchange](/wiki/Colombian_Stock_Exchange "Colombian Stock Exchange")
through the Latin American Integrated Market
([MILA](/wiki/Mercado_Integrado_Latinoamericano "Mercado Integrado
Latinoamericano")) offers a regional market to trade equities.[199][200]
Colombia is now one of only three economies with a perfect score on the
strength of legal rights index, according to the [World Bank](/wiki/World_Bank
"World Bank").[201]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/BVC_Bogota.jpg/170px-
BVC_Bogota.jpg)](/wiki/File:BVC_Bogota.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:BVC_Bogota.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Colombian Stock Exchange](/wiki/Colombian_Stock_Exchange "Colombian Stock
Exchange") is part of the Latin American Integrated Market
([MILA](/wiki/Mercado_Integrado_Latinoamericano "Mercado Integrado
Latinoamericano")).[202]

The electricity production in Colombia comes mainly from [renewable energy
sources](/wiki/Renewable_energy "Renewable energy"). 69.97% is obtained from
the [hydroelectric generation](/wiki/Hydroelectricity
"Hydroelectricity").[203] Colombia's commitment to renewable energy was
recognized in the 2014 _Global Green Economy Index (GGEI)_ , ranking among the
top 10 nations in the world in terms of greening efficiency sectors.[204]

Colombia is rich in natural resources, and its main exports include mineral
fuels, oils, [distillation
products](/wiki/Distillation#Industrial_distillation "Distillation"), fruit
and other agricultural products, sugars and sugar confectionery, [food
products](/wiki/Food_products "Food products"), plastics, precious stones,
metals, forest products, [chemical goods](/wiki/Chemical_industry "Chemical
industry"), [pharmaceuticals](/wiki/Pharmaceuticals "Pharmaceuticals"),
vehicles, electronic products, electrical equipments, perfumery and cosmetics,
machinery, manufactured articles, [textile](/wiki/Textile "Textile") and
fabrics, clothing and footwear, glass and glassware, furniture, prefabricated
buildings, military products, home and office material,
[construction](/wiki/Construction "Construction") equipment,
[software](/wiki/Software "Software"), among others.[205] Principal trading
partners are the United States, China, the European Union and some Latin
American countries.[206][207]

Non-traditional exports have boosted the growth of Colombian foreign sales as
well as the diversification of destinations of export thanks to new [free
trade agreements](/wiki/Free_trade_agreements "Free trade agreements").[208]

In 2016, the National Administrative Department of Statistics (DANE) reported
that 28.0% of the population were living below the poverty line, of which 8.5%
in "extreme poverty". The multidimensional poverty rate stands at 17.8 percent
of the population.[5] The Government has also been developing a process of
[financial inclusion](/wiki/Financial_inclusion "Financial inclusion") within
the country's most vulnerable population.[209]

Recent economic growth has led to a considerable increase of new millionaires,
including the new entrepreneurs, Colombians with a net worth exceeding US $1
billion.[210][211]

The contribution of [Travel & Tourism](/wiki/Tourism_in_Colombia "Tourism in
Colombia") to GDP was USD5,880.3bn (2.0% of total GDP) in 2016. Tourism
generated 556,135 jobs (2.5% of total employment) in 2016.[212] Foreign
tourist visits were predicted to have risen from 0.6 million in 2007 to 3.3
million in 2016.[213][214]

### Science and technology

Main article: [Science and technology in
Colombia](/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Colombia "Science and technology in
Colombia")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Colciencias_271215.JPG/220px-
Colciencias_271215.JPG)](/wiki/File:Colciencias_271215.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Colciencias_271215.JPG "Enlarge")

[COLCIENCIAS](/wiki/COLCIENCIAS "COLCIENCIAS") is a Colombian Government
agency that supports fundamental and applied research.

Colombia has more than 3,950 research groups in science and technology.[215]
iNNpulsa, a government body that promotes entrepreneurship and innovation in
the country, provides grants to startups, in addition to other services it and
institutions like Apps.co provide. Co-working spaces have arisen to serve as
communities for startups large and small.[216][217] Organizations such as the
Corporation for Biological Research (CIB) for the support of young people
interested in scientific work has been successfully developed in
Colombia.[218] The International Center for Tropical Agriculture based in
Colombia investigates the increasing challenge of [global
warming](/wiki/Global_warming "Global warming") and [food
security](/wiki/Food_security "Food security").[219]

Important inventions related to the medicine have been made in Colombia, such
as the first [external artificial pacemaker with internal
electrodes](/wiki/Artificial_cardiac_pacemaker "Artificial cardiac
pacemaker"), invented by the electronics engineer [Jorge Reynolds
Pombo](/wiki/Jorge_Reynolds_Pombo "Jorge Reynolds Pombo"), invention of great
importance for those who suffer from [heart failure](/wiki/Heart_failure
"Heart failure"). Also invented in Colombia were the
[microkeratome](/wiki/Microkeratome "Microkeratome") and keratomileusis
technique, which form the fundamental basis of what now is known as
[LASIK](/wiki/LASIK "LASIK") (one of the most important techniques for the
correction of [refractive errors](/wiki/Refractive_error "Refractive error")
of vision) and the [Hakim
valve](/wiki/Salom%C3%B3n_Hakim#The_Invention_of_the_valve "Salomón Hakim")
for the treatment of [Hydrocephalus](/wiki/Hydrocephalus "Hydrocephalus"),
among others.[220] Colombia has begun to innovate in military technology for
its army and other armies of the world; especially in the design and creation
of personal ballistic protection products, military hardware, [military
robots](/wiki/Military_robot "Military robot"), [bombs](/wiki/Bomb "Bomb"),
simulators and radar.[221][222][223]

Some leading Colombian scientists are Joseph M. Tohme, researcher recognized
for his work on the [genetic diversity](/wiki/Genetic_diversity "Genetic
diversity") of food, Manuel Elkin Patarroyo who is known for his
groundbreaking work on [synthetic vaccines](/wiki/Synthetic_vaccine "Synthetic
vaccine") for [malaria](/wiki/Malaria "Malaria"), Francisco Lopera who
discovered the "Paisa Mutation" or a type of [early-onset
Alzheimer's](/wiki/Early-onset_Alzheimer%27s_disease "Early-onset Alzheimer's
disease"),[224] [Rodolfo Llinás](/wiki/Rodolfo_Llin%C3%A1s "Rodolfo Llinás")
known for his study of the intrinsic [neurons](/wiki/Neuron "Neuron")
properties and the theory of a syndrome that had changed the way of
understanding the functioning of the brain, Jairo Quiroga Puello recognized
for his studies on the characterization of [synthetic
substances](/wiki/Synthetic_substance "Synthetic substance") which can be used
to fight [fungus](/wiki/Fungus "Fungus"), [tumors](/wiki/Tumor "Tumor"),
[tuberculosis](/wiki/Tuberculosis "Tuberculosis") and even some
[viruses](/wiki/Virus "Virus") and Ángela Restrepo who established accurate
[diagnoses](/wiki/Medical_diagnosis "Medical diagnosis") and treatments to
combat the effects of a disease caused by the _[Paracoccidioides
brasiliensis](/wiki/Paracoccidioides_brasiliensis "Paracoccidioides
brasiliensis")_ , among other [scientists](/wiki/Scientist
"Scientist").[225][226][227]

### Infrastructure

Main article: [Transport in Colombia](/wiki/Transport_in_Colombia "Transport
in Colombia")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Cartagena2011-Skyline-
Habour.jpg/190px-Cartagena2011-Skyline-
Habour.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cartagena2011-Skyline-Habour.jpg "Enlarge")

Port of [Cartagena](/wiki/Cartagena_de_Indias "Cartagena de Indias").

Transportation in Colombia is regulated within the functions of the [Ministry
of Transport](/wiki/Ministry_of_Transport_\(Colombia\) "Ministry of Transport
\(Colombia\)")[228] and entities such as the National Roads Institute
([INVÍAS](/wiki/INV%C3%8DAS "INVÍAS")) responsible for the [Highways in
Colombia](/wiki/Highways_in_Colombia "Highways in Colombia"),[229] the
[Aerocivil](/wiki/Aerocivil "Aerocivil"), responsible for civil aviation and
[airports](/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Colombia "List of airports in
Colombia"),[230] the [National Infrastructure
Agency](/wiki/National_Infrastructure_Agency_\(Colombia\) "National
Infrastructure Agency \(Colombia\)"), in charge of
[concessions](/wiki/Concession_\(contract\) "Concession \(contract\)") through
[public–private partnerships](/wiki/Public%E2%80%93private_partnership
"Public–private partnership"), for the design, construction, maintenance,
operation, and administration of the transport infrastructure,[231] the
General Maritime Directorate (Dimar) has the responsibility of coordinating
maritime traffic control along with the Colombian Navy,[232] among others and
under the supervision of the [Superintendency of Ports and
Transport](/wiki/Superintendency_of_Ports_and_Transport_\(Colombia\)
"Superintendency of Ports and Transport \(Colombia\)").[233] The road network
in Colombia has a length of about 215,000 km of which 23,000 are paved.[234]
[Rail transportation](/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Colombia "Rail transport in
Colombia") in Colombia is dedicated almost entirely to [freight
shipments](/wiki/Rail_freight_transport "Rail freight transport") and the
railway network has a length of 1,700 km of potentially active rails.[234]
Colombia has 3,960 kilometers of gas pipelines, 4,900 kilometers of [oil
pipelines](/wiki/Oil_pipelines "Oil pipelines"), and 2,990 kilometers of
refined-products pipelines.[234]

The target of Colombia's government is to build 7,000 km of roads for the
2016–2020 period and reduce travel times by 30 per cent and transport costs by
20 per cent. A toll road concession programme will comprise 40 projects, and
is part of a larger strategic goal to invest nearly $50bn in transport
infrastructure, including: railway systems; making the [Magdalena
river](/wiki/Magdalena_river "Magdalena river") navigable again; improving
port facilities; as well as an expansion of [Bogotá's
airport](/wiki/El_Dorado_International_Airport "El Dorado International
Airport").[235]

## Demographics

Main article: [Demographics of Colombia](/wiki/Demographics_of_Colombia
"Demographics of Colombia")

See also: [List of Colombian Departments by
population](/wiki/List_of_Colombian_Departments_by_population "List of
Colombian Departments by population")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Densidad_pop_col_only_Colombia.png/250px-
Densidad_pop_col_only_Colombia.png)](/wiki/File:Densidad_pop_col_only_Colombia.png)

[](/wiki/File:Densidad_pop_col_only_Colombia.png "Enlarge")

Population density of Colombia

With an estimated 49 million people in 2017, Colombia is the [third-most
populous country](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population "List of countries by
population") in Latin America, after Brazil and Mexico.[3] It is also home to
the third-largest number of [Spanish speakers](/wiki/Hispanophone
"Hispanophone") in the world after Mexico and the United States.[236] At the
beginning of the 20th century, Colombia's population was approximately 4
million.[237] Since the early 1970s Colombia has experienced steady declines
in its fertility, mortality, and [population growth](/wiki/Population_growth
"Population growth") rates. The population growth rate for 2015 is estimated
to be 0.9%.[238] The [total fertility rate](/wiki/Total_fertility_rate "Total
fertility rate") was 1.9 births per woman in 2015.[239] About 26.8% of the
population were 15 years old or younger, 65.7% were between 15 and 64 years
old, and 7.4% were over 65 years old. The proportion of older persons in the
total population has begun to increase substantially.[240] Colombia is
projected to have a population of 50.2 million by 2020 and 55.3 million by
2050.[241]

The population is concentrated in the [Andean
highlands](/wiki/Andean_Region_of_Colombia "Andean Region of Colombia") and
along the [Caribbean coast](/wiki/Caribbean_Region_of_Colombia "Caribbean
Region of Colombia"), also the population densities are generally higher in
the Andean region. The nine eastern lowland departments, comprising about 54%
of Colombia's area, have less than 6% of the population.[135][136]
Traditionally a rural society, [movement to urban areas](/wiki/Urbanization
"Urbanization") was very heavy in the mid-20th century, and Colombia is now
one of the most urbanized countries in Latin America. The urban population
increased from 31% of the total in 1938 to nearly 60% in 1973, and by 2014 the
figure stood at 76%.[242][243] The population of [Bogotá](/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1
"Bogotá") alone has increased from just over 300,000 in 1938 to approximately
8 million today.[244] In total seventy-two cities now have populations of
100,000 or more (2015).[245] As of
2012[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Colombia&action=edit)
Colombia has the world's largest populations of [internally displaced
persons](/wiki/Internally_displaced_person "Internally displaced person")
(IDPs), estimated to be up to 4.9 million people.[246]

The life expectancy is 74.8 years in 2015 and infant mortality is 13.6 per
thousand in 2015.[247][248] In 2015, 94.58% of adults and 98.66% of youth are
literate and the government spends about 4.49% of its GDP in education.[249]

Colombia is ranked third in the world in the [Happy Planet
Index](/wiki/Happy_Planet_Index "Happy Planet Index").

### Languages

Main article: [Languages of Colombia](/wiki/Languages_of_Colombia "Languages
of Colombia")

See also: [Colombian Spanish](/wiki/Colombian_Spanish "Colombian Spanish")

More than 99.2% of Colombians speak [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish
language"), also called Castilian; 65 [Amerindian
languages](/wiki/Amerindian_languages "Amerindian languages"), two [Creole
languages](/wiki/Creole_languages "Creole languages"), the [Romani
language](/wiki/Romani_language "Romani language") and [Colombian Sign
Language](/wiki/Colombian_Sign_Language "Colombian Sign Language") are also
spoken in the country. [English](/wiki/English_language "English language")
has official status in the [archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa
Catalina](/wiki/Archipelago_of_San_Andr%C3%A9s,_Providencia_and_Santa_Catalina
"Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa
Catalina").[8][250][251][252]

Including Spanish, a total of 101 languages are listed for Colombia in the
[Ethnologue](/wiki/Ethnologue "Ethnologue") database. The specific number of
spoken languages varies slightly since some authors consider as different
languages what others consider to be varieties or dialects of the same
language. Best estimates recorded 71 languages that are spoken in-country
today—most of which belong to the [Chibchan](/wiki/Chibchan_languages
"Chibchan languages"), [Tucanoan](/wiki/Tucanoan_languages "Tucanoan
languages"), [Bora–Witoto](/wiki/Bora%E2%80%93Witoto_languages "Bora–Witoto
languages"), [Guajiboan](/wiki/Guajiboan_languages "Guajiboan languages"),
[Arawakan](/wiki/Arawakan_languages "Arawakan languages"),
[Cariban](/wiki/Cariban_languages "Cariban languages"),
[Barbacoan](/wiki/Barbacoan_languages "Barbacoan languages"), and
[Saliban](/wiki/Piaroa%E2%80%93Saliban_languages "Piaroa–Saliban languages")
language families. There are currently about 850,000 speakers of native
languages.[253][254]

### Ethnic groups

Human biological diversity and ethnicity[1][2]  
---  
|  |  |  | Percentage  
[Mestizo](/wiki/Mestizo_Colombian "Mestizo Colombian") and [White](/wiki/White_Colombian "White Colombian") |  | 86%  
[Black](/wiki/Afro-Colombian "Afro-Colombian") (includes [Mulatto](/wiki/Mulatto "Mulatto")) |  | 10.6%  
[Amerindian](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia "Indigenous peoples in Colombia") |  | 3.4%  
[Roma](/wiki/Romani_people "Romani people") |  | 0.01%  
  
Main article: [Human biological diversity and ethnicity in
Colombia](/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_Colombia "Race and ethnicity in
Colombia")

Colombia is ethnically diverse, its people descending from the original
[native](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia "Indigenous peoples in
Colombia") inhabitants, [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_people "Spanish people")
colonists, [Africans](/wiki/African_Colombian "African Colombian") originally
brought to the country as slaves, and 20th-century [immigrants from
Europe](/wiki/European_diaspora "European diaspora") and the [Middle
East](/wiki/Arab_Colombians "Arab Colombians"), all contributing to a diverse
cultural heritage.[255] The demographic distribution reflects a pattern that
is influenced by colonial history.[256] Whites tend to live mainly in urban
centers, like [Bogotá](/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1 "Bogotá"),
[Medellín](/wiki/Medell%C3%ADn "Medellín") or [Cali](/wiki/Cali "Cali"), and
the burgeoning highland cities. The populations of the major cities also
include mestizos. [Mestizo](/wiki/Mestizo_Colombian "Mestizo Colombian")
_campesinos_ (people living in rural areas) also live in the Andean highlands
where some Spanish conquerors mixed with the women of Amerindian
[chiefdoms](/wiki/Chiefdoms "Chiefdoms"). Mestizos include artisans and small
tradesmen that have played a major part in the urban expansion of recent
decades.[257]

The 2005 census reported that the "non-ethnic population", consisting of
[whites](/wiki/White_Colombian "White Colombian") and
[mestizos](/wiki/Mestizo_Colombian "Mestizo Colombian") (those of mixed white
European and Amerindian ancestry), constituted 86% of the national population.
10.6% is of [African](/wiki/Afro-Colombian "Afro-Colombian") ancestry.
[Indigenous Amerindians](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia "Indigenous
peoples in Colombia") comprise 3.4% of the population. 0.01% of the population
are [Roma](/wiki/Romani_people "Romani people"). An extraofficial estimate
considers that the 49% of the Colombian population is
[Mestizo](/wiki/Mestizo_Colombian "Mestizo Colombian") or of mixed European
and Amerindian ancestry, and that approximately 37% is
[White](/wiki/White_Colombian "White Colombian"), mainly of
[Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_immigration_to_Colombia "Spanish immigration to
Colombia") lineage, but there is also a large population of [Middle
East](/wiki/Arab_Colombians "Arab Colombians") descent; in some sectors of
society there is a considerable input of [Italian](/wiki/Italian_Colombian
"Italian Colombian") and [German](/wiki/German_Colombian "German Colombian")
ancestry.[2]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_afrodescendiente_2005%29.svg/150px-
Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_afrodescendiente_2005%29.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Mapa_de_Colombia_\(poblaci%C3%B3n_afrodescendiente_2005\).svg)

People with [African ancestry](/wiki/African_Colombian "African Colombian") in
Colombia are concentrated mostly in coastal areas.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005%29.svg/150px-
Mapa_de_Colombia_%28poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005%29.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Mapa_de_Colombia_\(poblaci%C3%B3n_ind%C3%ADgena_2005\).svg)

[Amerindian](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia "Indigenous peoples in
Colombia") population of Colombia by municipality in 2005.

Many of the [Indigenous peoples](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Colombia
"Indigenous peoples in Colombia") experienced a reduction in population during
the Spanish rule[258] and many others were absorbed into the mestizo
population, but the remainder currently represents over eighty distinct
cultures. Reserves (_resguardos_) established for indigenous peoples occupy
30,571,640 hectares (305,716.4 km2) (27% of the country's total) and are
inhabited by more than 800,000 people.[259] Some of the largest indigenous
groups are the [Wayuu](/wiki/Wayuu "Wayuu"),[260] the [Paez](/wiki/Paez_people
"Paez people"), the
[Pastos](/w/index.php?title=Pastos_people&action=edit&redlink=1 "Pastos people
\(page does not exist\)"), the [Emberá](/wiki/Ember%C3%A1_people "Emberá
people") and the [Zenú](/wiki/Zen%C3%BA "Zenú").[261] The departments of [La
Guajira](/wiki/Department_of_La_Guajira "Department of La Guajira"),
[Cauca](/wiki/Cauca_Department "Cauca Department"),
[Nariño](/wiki/Nari%C3%B1o_Department "Nariño Department"),
[Córdoba](/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba_Department "Córdoba Department") and
[Sucre](/wiki/Sucre_Department "Sucre Department") have the largest indigenous
populations.[1]

The [Organización Nacional Indígena de
Colombia](/wiki/National_Indigenous_Organization_of_Colombia "National
Indigenous Organization of Colombia") (ONIC), founded at the first National
Indigenous Congress in 1982, is an organization representing the indigenous
peoples of Colombia. In 1991, Colombia signed and ratified the current
international law concerning indigenous peoples, [Indigenous and Tribal
Peoples Convention, 1989](/wiki/Indigenous_and_Tribal_Peoples_Convention,_1989
"Indigenous and Tribal Peoples Convention, 1989").[262]

[Black Africans](/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Africa "Ethnic groups of Africa") were
brought as [slaves](/wiki/Slavery "Slavery"), mostly to the coastal lowlands,
beginning early in the 16th century and continuing into the 19th century.
Large Afro-Colombian communities are found today on the Caribbean and Pacific
coasts. The population of the [department of
Chocó](/wiki/Choc%C3%B3_Department "Chocó Department"), running along the
northern portion of Colombia's Pacific coast, is over 80% black.[263]
[British](/wiki/British_people "British people") and
[Jamaicans](/wiki/Jamaican_people "Jamaican people") migrated mainly to the
islands of San Andres and Providencia. A number of other Europeans and North
Americans migrated to the country in the late 19th and early 20th centuries,
including people from the former [USSR](/wiki/USSR "USSR") during and after
the [Second World War](/wiki/Second_World_War "Second World War").[264][265]

Many immigrant communities have settled on the Caribbean coast, in particular
recent immigrants from the [Middle East](/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_West_Asia
"Ethnic groups in West Asia"). Barranquilla (the largest city of the Colombian
Caribbean) and other Caribbean cities have the largest populations of
[Lebanese](/wiki/Lebanese_Colombian "Lebanese Colombian"),
[Palestinian](/wiki/Palestinian_people "Palestinian people"), and other
[Arabs](/wiki/Arab_Colombians "Arab Colombians").[266][267] There are also
important communities of [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_people "Chinese people"),
[Japanese](/wiki/Japanese_Colombian "Japanese Colombian"),
[Romanis](/wiki/Romani_people "Romani people") and
[Jews](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Colombia "History of the Jews in
Colombia").[255] There is a major migration trend of
[Venezuelans](/wiki/Venezuelan_people "Venezuelan people"), due to the
political and economic situation in Venezuela.[268]

### Religion

Main article: [Religion in Colombia](/wiki/Religion_in_Colombia "Religion in
Colombia")

See also: [Freedom of religion in
Colombia](/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_Colombia "Freedom of religion in
Colombia")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Santuario_de_Las_Lajas%2C_Ipiales%2C_Colombia%2C_2015-07-21%2C_DD_21-23_HDR-
Edit.JPG/220px-
Santuario_de_Las_Lajas%2C_Ipiales%2C_Colombia%2C_2015-07-21%2C_DD_21-23_HDR-
Edit.JPG)](/wiki/File:Santuario_de_Las_Lajas,_Ipiales,_Colombia,_2015-07-21,_DD_21-23_HDR-
Edit.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Santuario_de_Las_Lajas,_Ipiales,_Colombia,_2015-07-21,_DD_21-23_HDR-
Edit.JPG "Enlarge")

The [Las Lajas Sanctuary](/wiki/Las_Lajas_Sanctuary "Las Lajas Sanctuary") in
the southern Colombian Department of [Nariño](/wiki/Nari%C3%B1o_Department
"Nariño Department")

The [National Administrative Department of
Statistics](/wiki/National_Administrative_Department_of_Statistics "National
Administrative Department of Statistics") (DANE) does not collect religious
statistics, and accurate reports are difficult to obtain. However, based on
various studies and a survey, about 90% of the population adheres to
[Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity"), the majority of which
(70.9%) are [Roman Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholic "Roman Catholic"), while a
significant minority (16.7%) adhere to [Protestantism](/wiki/Protestantism
"Protestantism") (primarily [Evangelicalism](/wiki/Evangelicalism
"Evangelicalism")). Some 4.7% of the population is [atheist](/wiki/Atheist
"Atheist") or [agnostic](/wiki/Agnostic "Agnostic"), while 3.5% claim to
believe in God but do not follow a specific religion. 1.8% of Colombians
adhere to [Jehovah's Witnesses](/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses "Jehovah's
Witnesses") and [Adventism](/wiki/Adventism "Adventism") and less than 1%
adhere to other religions, such as [Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam"),
[Judaism](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism"), [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism"),
[Mormonism](/wiki/Mormonism "Mormonism"), [Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism
"Hinduism"), [Indigenous religions](/wiki/Animism "Animism"), [Hare Krishna
movement](/wiki/Hare_Krishna_movement "Hare Krishna movement"), [Rastafari
movement](/wiki/Rastafari_movement "Rastafari movement"), [Orthodox Catholic
Church](/wiki/Orthodox_Catholic_Church "Orthodox Catholic Church"), and
spiritual studies. The remaining people either did not respond or replied that
they did not know. In addition to the above statistics, 35.9% of Colombians
reported that they did not practice their faith actively.[269][270][271]

While Colombia remains a mostly Roman Catholic country by
[baptism](/wiki/Baptism "Baptism") numbers, the 1991 Colombian constitution
guarantees freedom of religion and all religious faiths and churches are
equally free before the law.[272]

### Largest cities

Colombia is a highly urbanized country. The largest cities in the country are
[Bogotá](/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1 "Bogotá"), with an estimated 8 million inhabitants,
[Medellín](/wiki/Medell%C3%ADn "Medellín"), with an estimated 2.5 million
inhabitants, [Cali](/wiki/Cali "Cali"), with an estimated 2.4 million
inhabitants, and [Barranquilla](/wiki/Barranquilla "Barranquilla"), with an
estimated 1.2 million inhabitants. [Cartagena](/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia
"Cartagena, Colombia") highlights in number of inhabitants and the city of
[Bucaramanga](/wiki/Bucaramanga "Bucaramanga") is relevant in terms of
[metropolitan area population](/wiki/Metropolitan_areas_of_Colombia
"Metropolitan areas of Colombia").[245]

## Culture

Main article: [Culture of Colombia](/wiki/Culture_of_Colombia "Culture of
Colombia")

See also: [Festivals in Colombia](/wiki/Festivals_in_Colombia "Festivals in
Colombia") and [Colombian folklore](/wiki/Colombian_folklore "Colombian
folklore")

Colombia lies at the crossroads of [Latin
America](/wiki/Latin_American_culture "Latin American culture") and the
broader American continent, and as such has been hit by a wide range of
cultural influences. [Native
American](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Indigenous peoples of the
Americas"), [Spanish](/wiki/Culture_of_Spain "Culture of Spain") and other
[European](/wiki/Culture_of_Europe "Culture of Europe"),
[African](/wiki/Culture_of_Africa "Culture of Africa"),
[American](/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_States "Culture of the United States"),
[Caribbean](/wiki/Culture_of_the_Caribbean "Culture of the Caribbean"), and
[Middle Eastern](/wiki/Arab_culture "Arab culture") influences, as well as
other Latin American cultural influences, are all present in Colombia's modern
culture. Urban migration, industrialization, globalization, and other
political, social and economic changes have also left an impression.

Many [national symbols](/wiki/National_symbols_of_Colombia "National symbols
of Colombia"), both objects and themes, have arisen from Colombia's diverse
cultural traditions and aim to represent what Colombia, and the Colombian
people, have in common. Cultural expressions in Colombia are promoted by the
government through the [Ministry of
Culture](/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_\(Colombia\) "Ministry of Culture
\(Colombia\)").

### Literature

Main article: [Colombian literature](/wiki/Colombian_literature "Colombian
literature")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez%2C_2009.jpg/220px-
Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez%2C_2009.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez,_2009.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gabriel_Garcia_Marquez,_2009.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Nobel literature](/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_in_Literature "List of
Nobel laureates in Literature") prize winner [Gabriel García
Márquez](/wiki/Gabriel_Garc%C3%ADa_M%C3%A1rquez "Gabriel García Márquez")[273]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Fi_322_Isaacs%2C_Jorge.jpg/170px-
Fi_322_Isaacs%2C_Jorge.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fi_322_Isaacs,_Jorge.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Fi_322_Isaacs,_Jorge.jpg "Enlarge")

[Jorge Isaacs](/wiki/Jorge_Isaacs "Jorge Isaacs") was one of the greatest
exponents of Colombian literature in the nineteenth century.

Colombian literature dates back to pre-Columbian era; a notable example of the
period is the epic poem known as the _Legend of Yurupary_.[274] In Spanish
colonial times, notable writers include [Juan de
Castellanos](/wiki/Juan_de_Castellanos "Juan de Castellanos") (_[Elegías de
varones ilustres de Indias](/wiki/Eleg%C3%ADas_de_varones_ilustres_de_Indias
"Elegías de varones ilustres de Indias")_), Hernando Domínguez Camargo and his
epic poem to San Ignacio de Loyola, [Pedro Simón](/wiki/Pedro_Sim%C3%B3n
"Pedro Simón"), [Juan Rodríguez Freyle](/wiki/Juan_Rodr%C3%ADguez_Freyle "Juan
Rodríguez Freyle") (_[El Carnero](/wiki/El_Carnero "El Carnero")_),[275]
[Lucas Fernández de Piedrahita](/wiki/Lucas_Fern%C3%A1ndez_de_Piedrahita
"Lucas Fernández de Piedrahita"), and the nun [Francisca Josefa de
Castillo](/wiki/Francisca_Josefa_de_la_Concepci%C3%B3n "Francisca Josefa de la
Concepción"), representative of [mysticism](/wiki/Mysticism "Mysticism").

Post-independence literature linked to Romanticism highlighted [Antonio
Nariño](/wiki/Antonio_Nari%C3%B1o "Antonio Nariño"), [José Fernández
Madrid](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Fern%C3%A1ndez_Madrid "José Fernández Madrid"),
[Camilo Torres Tenorio](/wiki/Camilo_Torres_Tenorio "Camilo Torres Tenorio")
and [Francisco Antonio Zea](/wiki/Francisco_Antonio_Zea "Francisco Antonio
Zea").[276][277] In the second half of the nineteenth century and early
twentieth century the literary genre known as
_[costumbrismo](/wiki/Costumbrismo "Costumbrismo")_ became popular; great
writers of this period were [Tomás Carrasquilla](/wiki/Tom%C3%A1s_Carrasquilla
"Tomás Carrasquilla"), [Jorge Isaacs](/wiki/Jorge_Isaacs "Jorge Isaacs") and
[Rafael Pombo](/wiki/Rafael_Pombo "Rafael Pombo") (the latter of whom wrote
notable works of children's literature).[278][279] Within that period, authors
such as [José Asunción Silva](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Asunci%C3%B3n_Silva "José
Asunción Silva"), [José Eustasio Rivera](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Eustasio_Rivera "José
Eustasio Rivera"), [León de Greiff](/wiki/Le%C3%B3n_de_Greiff "León de
Greiff"), [Porfirio Barba-Jacob](/wiki/Porfirio_Barba-Jacob "Porfirio Barba-
Jacob") and [José María Vargas Vila](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Vargas_Vila
"José María Vargas Vila") developed the [modernist](/wiki/Modernismo
"Modernismo") movement.[280][281][282] In 1872, Colombia established the
[Colombian Academy of Language](/wiki/Colombian_Academy_of_Language "Colombian
Academy of Language"), the first Spanish language academy in the
Americas.[283] Candelario Obeso wrote the groundbreaking _Cantos Populares de
mi Tierra_ (1877), the first book of poetry by an Afro-Colombian
author.[284][285]

Between 1939 and 1940 seven books of poetry were published under the name
_[Stone and Sky](/wiki/Stone_and_Sky_\(movement\) "Stone and Sky
\(movement\)")_ in the city of Bogotá that significantly impacted the country;
they were edited by the poet Jorge Rojas.[286] In the following decade,
[Gonzalo Arango](/wiki/Gonzalo_Arango "Gonzalo Arango") founded the movement
of "[nothingness](/wiki/Nadaism "Nadaism")" in response to the violence of the
time;[287] he was influenced by [nihilism](/wiki/Nihilism "Nihilism"),
[existentialism](/wiki/Existentialism "Existentialism"), and the thought of
another great Colombian writer: [Fernando González
Ochoa](/wiki/Fernando_Gonz%C3%A1lez_\(writer\) "Fernando González
\(writer\)").[288] During the [boom in Latin American
literature](/wiki/Latin_American_Boom "Latin American Boom"), successful
writers emerged, led by [Nobel laureate](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature
"Nobel Prize in Literature") [Gabriel García
Márquez](/wiki/Gabriel_Garc%C3%ADa_M%C3%A1rquez "Gabriel García Márquez") and
his magnum opus, _[One Hundred Years of
Solitude](/wiki/One_Hundred_Years_of_Solitude "One Hundred Years of
Solitude")_ , [Eduardo Caballero
Calderón](/wiki/Eduardo_Caballero_Calder%C3%B3n "Eduardo Caballero Calderón"),
[Manuel Mejía Vallejo](/wiki/Manuel_Mej%C3%ADa_Vallejo "Manuel Mejía
Vallejo"), and [Álvaro Mutis](/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Mutis "Álvaro Mutis"), a
writer who was awarded the [Cervantes Prize](/wiki/Miguel_de_Cervantes_Prize
"Miguel de Cervantes Prize") and the [Prince of Asturias Award for
Letters](/wiki/Prince_of_Asturias_Award_for_Letters "Prince of Asturias Award
for Letters").[289][290] Other leading contemporary authors are [Fernando
Vallejo](/wiki/Fernando_Vallejo "Fernando Vallejo"), [William
Ospina](/wiki/William_Ospina "William Ospina") ([Rómulo Gallegos
Prize](/wiki/R%C3%B3mulo_Gallegos_Prize "Rómulo Gallegos Prize")) and [Germán
Castro Caycedo](/wiki/Germ%C3%A1n_Castro_Caycedo "Germán Castro Caycedo").

### Visual arts

Main article: [Colombian art](/wiki/Colombian_art "Colombian art")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Monumento_pantano_de_vargas%2C_completo._2006.JPG/220px-
Monumento_pantano_de_vargas%2C_completo._2006.JPG)](/wiki/File:Monumento_pantano_de_vargas,_completo._2006.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Monumento_pantano_de_vargas,_completo._2006.JPG "Enlarge")

[Vargas Swamp Lancers](/wiki/Vargas_Swamp_Lancers "Vargas Swamp Lancers"),
artwork by [Rodrigo Arenas Betancourt](/wiki/Rodrigo_Arenas_Betancourt
"Rodrigo Arenas Betancourt")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/AdamandEve-
FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg/180px-AdamandEve-
FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg)](/wiki/File:AdamandEve-
FernandoBotero-20100414.jpg)

Work of the painter, and sculptor [Fernando Botero](/wiki/Fernando_Botero
"Fernando Botero")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Santiago_Martinez_Delgado_in_the_colombian_congress.jpg/180px-
Santiago_Martinez_Delgado_in_the_colombian_congress.jpg)](/wiki/File:Santiago_Martinez_Delgado_in_the_colombian_congress.jpg)

Mural by [Santiago Martínez Delgado](/wiki/Santiago_Mart%C3%ADnez_Delgado
"Santiago Martínez Delgado")

Colombian art has over 3,000 years of history. Colombian artists have captured
the country's changing political and cultural backdrop using a range of styles
and mediums. There is archeological evidence of ceramics being produced
earlier in Colombia than anywhere else in the Americas, dating as early as
3,000 BCE.[291][292]

The earliest examples of gold craftsmanship have been attributed to the Tumaco
people[293] of the Pacific coast and date to around 325 BCE. Roughly between
200 BCE and 800 CE, the [San Agustín culture](/wiki/San_Agust%C3%ADn,_Huila
"San Agustín, Huila"), masters of [stonecutting](/wiki/Stonemasonry
"Stonemasonry"), entered its "classical period". They erected raised
[ceremonial](/wiki/Ceremony "Ceremony") centres, [sarcophagi](/wiki/Sarcophagi
"Sarcophagi"), and large stone [monoliths](/wiki/Monolith "Monolith")
depicting [anthropomorphic](/wiki/Anthropomorphic "Anthropomorphic") and
[zoomorphhic](/wiki/Zoomorphism "Zoomorphism") forms out of
[stone](/wiki/Rock_\(geology\) "Rock \(geology\)").[292][294]

Colombian art has followed the trends of the time, so during the 16th to 18th
centuries, [Spanish Catholicism](/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Spain "Roman
Catholicism in Spain") had a huge influence on Colombian art, and the popular
[baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque") style was replaced with
[rococo](/wiki/Rococo "Rococo") when the Bourbons ascended to the [Spanish
crown](/wiki/Monarchy_of_Spain "Monarchy of Spain").[295][296] More recently,
Colombian artists [Pedro Nel Gómez](/wiki/Pedro_Nel_G%C3%B3mez "Pedro Nel
Gómez") and [Santiago Martínez Delgado](/wiki/Santiago_Mart%C3%ADnez_Delgado
"Santiago Martínez Delgado") started the Colombian Murial Movement in the
1940s, featuring the [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassicism "Neoclassicism")
features of [Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco "Art Deco").[291][292][297][298]

Since the 1950s, the Colombian art started to have a distinctive point of
view, reinventing traditional elements under the concepts of the 20th century.
Examples of this are the Greiff [portraits](/wiki/Portrait "Portrait") by
[Ignacio Gómez Jaramillo](/wiki/Ignacio_G%C3%B3mez_Jaramillo "Ignacio Gómez
Jaramillo"), showing what the Colombian art could do with the new techniques
applied to typical Colombian themes. Carlos Correa, with his
[paradigmatic](/wiki/Paradigm "Paradigm") "Naturaleza muerta en silencio"
(silent dead nature), combines geometrical
[abstraction](/wiki/Abstraction_\(art\) "Abstraction \(art\)") and
[cubism](/wiki/Cubism "Cubism"). [Alejandro
Obregón](/wiki/Alejandro_Obreg%C3%B3n "Alejandro Obregón") is often considered
as the father of modern Colombian painting, and one of the most influential
artist in this period, due to his originality, the painting of Colombian
landscapes with [symbolic](/wiki/Symbolism_\(arts\) "Symbolism \(arts\)") and
[expressionist](/wiki/Expressionism "Expressionism") use of animals,
(specially the [Andean condor](/wiki/Andean_condor "Andean
condor")).[292][299][300] [Fernando Botero](/wiki/Fernando_Botero "Fernando
Botero"), [Omar Rayo](/wiki/Omar_Rayo "Omar Rayo"), [Enrique
Grau](/wiki/Enrique_Grau "Enrique Grau"), [Édgar
Negret](/wiki/%C3%89dgar_Negret "Édgar Negret"), [David
Manzur](/wiki/David_Manzur "David Manzur"), [Rodrigo Arenas
Betancourt](/wiki/Rodrigo_Arenas_Betancourt "Rodrigo Arenas Betancourt") and
[Oscar Murillo](/wiki/Oscar_Murillo_\(artist\) "Oscar Murillo \(artist\)") are
some of the Colombian artists featured at the international
level.[291][301][302][303]

The Colombian sculpture from the sixteenth to 18th centuries was mostly
devoted to [religious depictions](/wiki/Religious_art "Religious art") of
ecclesiastic art, strongly influenced by the Spanish schools of
[sacred](/wiki/Sacred "Sacred") sculpture. During the early period of the
Colombian republic, the national artists were focused in the production of
sculptural portraits of politicians and public figures, in a plain
[neoclassicist](/wiki/Neoclassicist "Neoclassicist") trend.[304] During the
20th century, the Colombian sculpture began to develop a bold and innovative
work with the aim of reaching a better understanding of national
sensitivity.[292][305]

Colombian photography was marked by the arrival of the
[daguerreotype](/wiki/Daguerreotype "Daguerreotype"). [Jean-Baptiste Louis
Gros](/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Louis_Gros "Jean-Baptiste Louis Gros") was who
brought the daguerreotype process to Colombia in 1841. The Piloto public
library has Latin America's largest archive of negatives, containing 1.7
million antique photographs covering Colombia 1848 until 2005.[306][307]

The Colombian press has promoted the work of the
[cartoonists](/wiki/Cartoonist "Cartoonist"). In recent decades,
[fanzines](/wiki/Fanzine "Fanzine"), internet and [independent
publishers](/wiki/Independent_publisher "Independent publisher") have been
fundamental to the growth of the [comic](/wiki/Comic "Comic") in
Colombia.[308][309][310]

### Architecture

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Torres_del_parque_torre_B.JPG/200px-
Torres_del_parque_torre_B.JPG)](/wiki/File:Torres_del_parque_torre_B.JPG)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Tombs_in_Tierra_Dentro_-_3.jpg/200px-
Tombs_in_Tierra_Dentro_-_3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tombs_in_Tierra_Dentro_-_3.jpg)

Monumental hypogea of the [Tierradentro](/wiki/Tierradentro "Tierradentro")

Main article: [Architecture of Colombia](/wiki/Architecture_of_Colombia
"Architecture of Colombia")

See also: [Muisca architecture](/wiki/Muisca_architecture "Muisca
architecture")

Throughout the times, there have been a variety of [architectural
styles](/wiki/List_of_architectural_styles "List of architectural styles"),
from those of indigenous peoples to contemporary ones, passing through
colonial (military and religious), Republican, transition and modern
styles.[311]

Ancient habitation areas, longhouses, [crop
terraces](/wiki/Terrace_\(agriculture\) "Terrace \(agriculture\)"), roads as
the [Inca road system](/wiki/Inca_road_system "Inca road system"), cemeteries,
[hypogeums](/wiki/Hypogeum "Hypogeum") and [necropolises](/wiki/Necropolis
"Necropolis") are all part of the [architectural heritage of indigenous
peoples](/wiki/Indigenous_architecture "Indigenous architecture").[312] Some
prominent indigenous structures are the [preceramic](/wiki/Andean_preceramic
"Andean preceramic") and [ceramic](/wiki/Ceramic "Ceramic") archaeological
site of [Tequendama](/wiki/Tequendama "Tequendama"),[313]
[Tierradentro](/wiki/Tierradentro "Tierradentro") (a park that contains the
largest concentration of [pre-Columbian](/wiki/List_of_pre-Columbian_cultures
"List of pre-Columbian cultures") monumental [shaft tombs](/wiki/Shaft_tomb
"Shaft tomb") with side chambers),[314] the largest collection of religious
[monuments](/wiki/Monument "Monument") and [megalithic](/wiki/Megalithic
"Megalithic") sculptures in South America, located in [San Agustín,
Huila](/wiki/San_Agust%C3%ADn_Archaeological_Park "San Agustín Archaeological
Park"),[294][315] [Lost city](/wiki/Ciudad_Perdida "Ciudad Perdida") (an
archaeological site with a series of terraces carved into the mountainside, a
net of tiled roads and several circular plazas) and also stand out the large
villages mainly built with [stone](/wiki/Stone "Stone"), wood, cane and
mud.[316]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-
_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg/220px-Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-
_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg)](/wiki/File:Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Santa_B%C3%A1rbara_-_Momp%C3%B3s.jpg "Enlarge")

Historic Centre of [Santa Cruz de Mompox](/wiki/Santa_Cruz_de_Mompox "Santa
Cruz de Mompox"), an architectural site with colonial elements

Architecture during the period of conquest and colonization is mainly derived
of adapting [European styles](/wiki/European_architecture "European
architecture") to local conditions, and [Spanish
influence](/wiki/Spanish_architecture "Spanish architecture"), especially
[Andalusian](/wiki/Andalusia "Andalusia") and [Extremaduran](/wiki/Extremadura
"Extremadura"), can be easily seen.[317] When Europeans founded cities two
things were making simultaneously: the dimensioning of geometrical space
([town square](/wiki/Town_square "Town square"), street), and the location of
a tangible point of [orientation](/wiki/Map_orientation "Map
orientation").[318] The construction of [forts](/wiki/Fort "Fort") was common
throughout the Caribbean and in some cities of the interior, because of the
dangers that represented the English, French, and Dutch
[pirates](/wiki/Piracy_in_the_Caribbean "Piracy in the Caribbean") and the
hostile indigenous groups.[319] Churches, chapels, schools, and hospitals
belonging to [religious orders](/wiki/Catholic_religious_order "Catholic
religious order") cause a great urban impact.[320] [Baroque
architecture](/wiki/Baroque_architecture "Baroque architecture") is used in
military buildings and public spaces.[321] Marcelino Arroyo, [Francisco José
de Caldas](/wiki/Francisco_Jos%C3%A9_de_Caldas "Francisco José de Caldas") and
Domingo de Petrés were great representatives of [neo-classical
architecture](/wiki/Neo-classical_architecture "Neo-classical
architecture").[320]

The [National Capitol](/wiki/Capitolio_Nacional "Capitolio Nacional") is a
great representative of romanticism.[322] Wood is extensively used in doors,
windows, railings and ceilings during the colonization of
[Antioquia](/wiki/Antioquia_Department "Antioquia Department"). The
[Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean_region_of_Colombia "Caribbean region of Colombia")
architecture acquires a strong [Arabic influence](/wiki/Arabic_architecture
"Arabic architecture").[323] The [Teatro
Colón](/wiki/Teatro_de_Crist%C3%B3bal_Col%C3%B3n "Teatro de Cristóbal Colón")
in Bogotá is a lavish example of architecture from the 19th century.[324] The
quintas houses with innovations in the [volumetric](/wiki/Volumetric
"Volumetric") conception are some of the best examples of the Republican
architecture; the Republican action in the city focused on the
[design](/wiki/Design "Design") of three types of
[spaces](/wiki/Spatial_analysis "Spatial analysis"): parks with forests, small
[urban parks](/wiki/Urban_park "Urban park") and
[avenues](/wiki/Avenue_\(landscape\) "Avenue \(landscape\)") and the [Gothic
style](/wiki/Gothic_architecture "Gothic architecture") was most commonly used
for the design of churches.[325]

Deco style, [modern neoclassicism](/wiki/Rationalism_\(architecture\)
"Rationalism \(architecture\)"),
[eclecticism](/wiki/Eclecticism_in_architecture "Eclecticism in architecture")
[folklorist](/wiki/Folklorist "Folklorist") and [art deco](/wiki/Art_deco "Art
deco") [ornamental](/wiki/Ornament_\(art\) "Ornament \(art\)") resources
significantly influenced the architecture of Colombia, especially during the
transition period.[326] [Modernism](/wiki/International_Style_\(architecture\)
"International Style \(architecture\)") contributed with new construction
technologies and new [materials](/wiki/Building_material "Building material")
(steel, [reinforced concrete](/wiki/Reinforced_concrete "Reinforced
concrete"), glass and synthetic materials) and the [topology](/wiki/Topology
"Topology") architecture and [lightened slabs system](/wiki/Concrete_slab
"Concrete slab") also have a great influence.[327] The most influential
architects of the modern movement were [Rogelio Salmona](/wiki/Rogelio_Salmona
"Rogelio Salmona") and Fernando Martínez Sanabria.[328]

The [contemporary architecture](/wiki/Contemporary_architecture "Contemporary
architecture") of Colombia is designed to give greater importance to the
[materials](/wiki/Building_material "Building material"), this architecture
takes into account the specific [natural and artificial
geographies](/wiki/Geographical_feature "Geographical feature") and is also an
architecture that appeals to the [senses](/wiki/Sense "Sense").[329] The
[conservation of the architectural and urban
heritage](/wiki/Architectural_conservation "Architectural conservation") of
Colombia has been promoted in recent years.[330]

### Music

Main article: [Music of Colombia](/wiki/Music_of_Colombia "Music of Colombia")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png/175px-
Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png)](/wiki/File:Ejes_musicales_de_Colombia1.png)

[Musical Regions](/wiki/Music_of_Colombia "Music of Colombia") of Colombia.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Tiple.jpg/147px-
Tiple.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tiple.jpg)

[Colombian tiple](/wiki/Colombian_tiple "Colombian tiple")

Colombia has a vibrant collage of talent that touches a full spectrum of
[rhythms](/wiki/Rhythm "Rhythm"). Musicians, composers, music producers and
singers from Colombia are recognized internationally such as
[Shakira](/wiki/Shakira "Shakira"), [Juanes](/wiki/Juanes "Juanes"), [Carlos
Vives](/wiki/Carlos_Vives "Carlos Vives") and others.[331] Colombian music
blends European-influenced [guitar](/wiki/Guitar "Guitar") and song structure
with large gaita [flutes](/wiki/Flute "Flute") and [percussion
instruments](/wiki/Percussion_instrument "Percussion instrument") from the
indigenous population, while its percussion structure and [dance](/wiki/Dance
"Dance") forms come from Africa. Colombia has a diverse and dynamic musical
environment.[332]

[Guillermo Uribe Holguín](/wiki/Guillermo_Uribe_Holgu%C3%ADn "Guillermo Uribe
Holguín"), an important cultural figure in the [National Symphony Orchestra of
Colombia](/wiki/National_Symphony_Orchestra_of_Colombia "National Symphony
Orchestra of Colombia"), Luis Antonio Calvo and Blas Emilio Atehortúa are some
of the greatest exponents of the [art music](/wiki/Art_music "Art
music").[333] The [Bogotá Philharmonic
Orchestra](/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1_Philharmonic_Orchestra "Bogotá Philharmonic
Orchestra") is one of the most active orchestras in Colombia.[334]

Caribbean music has many vibrant rhythms, such as
[cumbia](/wiki/Cumbia_\(Colombia\) "Cumbia \(Colombia\)") (it is played by the
maracas, the drums, the gaitas and [guacharaca](/wiki/Guacharaca
"Guacharaca")), [porro](/wiki/Porro "Porro") (it is a monotonous but joyful
rhythm), [mapalé](/wiki/Mapal%C3%A9 "Mapalé") (with its fast rhythm and
constant clapping) and the "[vallenato](/wiki/Vallenato "Vallenato")", which
originated in the northern part of the Caribbean coast (the rhythm is mainly
played by the caja, the guacharaca, and [accordion](/wiki/Accordion
"Accordion")).[335][336][337][338][339]

The music from the Pacific coast, such as the
[currulao](/wiki/Currulao_\(music_genre\) "Currulao \(music genre\)") is
characterized by its strong use of [drums](/wiki/Drum "Drum") (instruments
such as the native [marimba](/wiki/Marimba "Marimba"), the conunos, the [bass
drum](/wiki/Bass_drum "Bass drum"), the [side drum](/wiki/Side_drum "Side
drum") and the cuatro guasas or tubular rattle). An important rhythm of the
south region of the Pacific coast is the [contradanza](/wiki/Contradanza
"Contradanza") (it is used in dance shows, as a result of the striking colours
of the costumes).[335][340][341] Marimba music, traditional chants and dances
from the Colombia South Pacific region are on [UNESCO's Representative List of
the Intangible Cultural Heritage of
Humanity](/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists "UNESCO Intangible
Cultural Heritage Lists").[342][343][344]

Important musical rhythms of the Andean Region are the danza (dance of Andean
folklore arising from the transformation of the European contredance), the
[bambuco](/wiki/Bambuco "Bambuco") (it is played with guitar,
[tiple](/wiki/Colombian_tiple "Colombian tiple")[345] and
[mandolin](/wiki/Mandolin "Mandolin"), the rhythm is danced by couples), the
[pasillo](/wiki/Pasillo "Pasillo") (a rhythm inspired by the Austrian
[waltz](/wiki/Waltz "Waltz") and the Colombian "danza", the lyrics have been
composed by well-known poets), the guabina (the tiple, the
[bandola](/wiki/Bandola "Bandola") and the [requinto](/wiki/Requinto
"Requinto") are the basic instruments), the [sanjuanero](/wiki/Sanjuanero
"Sanjuanero") (it originated in Tolima and Huila Departments, the rhythm is
joyful and fast).[346][347][348][349][350] Apart from these traditional
rhythms, [salsa music](/wiki/Salsa_music "Salsa music") has spread throughout
the country, and the city of [Cali](/wiki/Cali "Cali") is considered by many
salsa singers to be 'The New Salsa Capital of the World'.[335][351][352]

![File:Bailarines de Salsa en
Cali.webm](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm/220px
--Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm.jpg)[Play
media](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a7/Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm
"Play media")

[](/wiki/File:Bailarines_de_Salsa_en_Cali.webm "Enlarge")

Colombian-style salsa dancing

The instruments that distinguish the music of the [Eastern
Plains](/wiki/Orinoqu%C3%ADa_natural_region "Orinoquía natural region") are
the [harp](/wiki/Harp "Harp"), the [cuatro](/wiki/Cuatro_\(instrument\)
"Cuatro \(instrument\)") (a type of four-stringed guitar) and maracas.
Important rhythms of this region are the [joropo](/wiki/Joropo "Joropo") (a
fast rhythm and there is also tapping as a result of its
[flamenco](/wiki/Flamenco "Flamenco") ancestry) and the
[galeron](/wiki/Galeron "Galeron") (it is heard a lot while cowboys are
working).[335][353][354][355]

The music of the Amazon region is strongly influenced by the indigenous
religious practices. Some of the musical instruments used are the manguaré (a
musical instrument of [ceremonial](/wiki/Ceremonial "Ceremonial") type,
consisting of a pair of large cylindrical drums), the [quena](/wiki/Quena
"Quena") (melodic instrument), the [rondador](/wiki/Rondador "Rondador"), the
[congas](/wiki/Conga "Conga"), [bells](/wiki/Bell "Bell"), and different types
of flutes.[356][357][358]

The music of the Archipelago of San Andrés, Providencia and Santa Catalina is
usually accompanied by a mandolin, a [tub-bass](/wiki/Washtub_bass "Washtub
bass"), a jawbone, a guitar and [maracas](/wiki/Maraca "Maraca"). Some popular
archipelago rhythms are the [Schottische](/wiki/Schottische "Schottische"),
the [Calypso](/wiki/Calypso_music "Calypso music"), the Polka and the
[Mento](/wiki/Mento "Mento").[359][360]

### Popular culture

Main articles: [Theater of Colombia](/wiki/Theater_of_Colombia "Theater of
Colombia"), [Cinema of Colombia](/wiki/Cinema_of_Colombia "Cinema of
Colombia"), and [Media of Colombia](/wiki/Media_of_Colombia "Media of
Colombia")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg/180px-
Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg)](/wiki/File:Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Interior_Teatro_Colon_Bogota.jpg "Enlarge")

The Ibero-American Theater Festival of Bogotá is one of the biggest theater
festivals in the world.[361]

Theater was introduced in Colombia during the [Spanish
colonization](/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas "Spanish colonization
of the Americas") in 1550 through [zarzuela](/wiki/Zarzuela "Zarzuela")
companies. Colombian theater is supported by the Ministry of Culture and a
number of private and state owned organizations. The [Ibero-American Theater
Festival of Bogotá](/wiki/Theater_of_Colombia "Theater of Colombia") is the
cultural event of the highest importance in Colombia and one of the biggest
theater festivals in the world.[361] Other important theater events are: The
Festival of Puppet The Fanfare (Medellín), The Manizales Theater Festival, The
Caribbean Theatre Festival (Santa Marta) and The Art Festival of Popular
Culture "Cultural Invasion" (Bogotá).[362][363][364]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG/200px-
Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG)](/wiki/File:Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Statue_India_Catalina_FICCI.JPG "Enlarge")

The [Cartagena Film Festival](/wiki/Cartagena_Film_Festival "Cartagena Film
Festival") is the oldest cinema event in Latin America. The central focus is
on films from Ibero-America.[365]

Although the [Colombian cinema](/wiki/Cinema_of_Colombia "Cinema of Colombia")
is young as an industry, more recently the film industry was growing with
support from the Film Act passed in 2003.[366] Many film festivals take place
in Colombia, but the two most important are the [Cartagena Film
Festival](/wiki/Cartagena_Film_Festival "Cartagena Film Festival"), which is
the oldest film festival in Latin America, and the [Bogotá Film
Festival](/wiki/Bogot%C3%A1_Film_Festival "Bogotá Film
Festival").[365][367][368]

Some important national circulation newspapers are _[El
Tiempo](/wiki/El_Tiempo_\(Colombia\) "El Tiempo \(Colombia\)")_ and _[El
Espectador](/wiki/El_Espectador "El Espectador")_. [Television in
Colombia](/wiki/Television_in_Colombia "Television in Colombia") has two
privately owned TV networks and three state-owned TV networks with national
coverage, as well as six regional TV networks and dozens of local TV stations.
Private channels, [RCN](/wiki/RCN_TV "RCN TV") and
[Caracol](/wiki/Caracol_Televisi%C3%B3n "Caracol Televisión") are the highest-
rated. The regional channels and regional newspapers cover a department or
more and its content is made in these particular areas.[369][370][371]

Colombia has three major national [radio networks](/wiki/Radio_in_Colombia
"Radio in Colombia"): [Radiodifusora Nacional de
Colombia](/wiki/Radiodifusora_Nacional_de_Colombia "Radiodifusora Nacional de
Colombia"), a state-run national radio; [Caracol Radio](/wiki/Caracol_Radio
"Caracol Radio") and [RCN Radio](/wiki/RCN_Radio "RCN Radio"), privately owned
networks with hundreds of affiliates. There are other national networks,
including [Cadena Super](/wiki/Cadena_Super "Cadena Super"),
[Todelar](/wiki/Todelar "Todelar"), and Colmundo. Many hundreds of radio
stations are registered with the [Ministry of Information Technologies and
Communications](/wiki/Ministry_of_Information_Technologies_and_Communications_\(Colombia\)
"Ministry of Information Technologies and Communications \(Colombia\)").[372]

### Cuisine

Main article: [Colombian cuisine](/wiki/Colombian_cuisine "Colombian cuisine")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg/220px-
Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sancocho_de_gallina_criolla.jpg "Enlarge")

Sancocho de gallina criolla is a traditional soup in Colombia.

Colombia's varied cuisine is influenced by its diverse fauna and flora as well
as the cultural traditions of the ethnic groups. Colombian dishes and
ingredients vary widely by region. Some of the most common ingredients are:
cereals such as rice and maize; tubers such as potato and
[cassava](/wiki/Cassava "Cassava"); assorted [legumes](/wiki/Legume "Legume");
meats, including beef, chicken, pork and goat; fish; and seafood.[373][374]
Colombia cuisine also features a variety of tropical [fruits](/wiki/Fruit
"Fruit") such as [cape gooseberry](/wiki/Physalis_peruviana "Physalis
peruviana"), [feijoa](/wiki/Acca_sellowiana "Acca sellowiana"),
[arazá](/wiki/Eugenia_stipitata "Eugenia stipitata"), [dragon
fruit](/wiki/Pitaya "Pitaya"), [mangostino](/wiki/Purple_mangosteen "Purple
mangosteen"), [granadilla](/wiki/Passiflora_ligularis "Passiflora ligularis"),
[papaya](/wiki/Papaya "Papaya"), [guava](/wiki/Guava "Guava"), mora
([blackberry](/wiki/Blackberry "Blackberry")), [lulo](/wiki/Solanum_quitoense
"Solanum quitoense"), [soursop](/wiki/Annona_muricata "Annona muricata") and
[passionfruit](/wiki/Passionfruit "Passionfruit").[375] Colombia is one of the
world's largest consumers of fruit [juices](/wiki/Juice "Juice").[376]

Among the most representative appetizers and soups are
[patacones](/wiki/Tostones "Tostones") (fried green plantains),
[sancocho](/wiki/Sancocho "Sancocho") de gallina (chicken soup with root
vegetables) and [ajiaco](/wiki/Ajiaco "Ajiaco") (potato and corn soup).
Representative snacks and breads are [pandebono](/wiki/Pandebono "Pandebono"),
[arepas](/wiki/Arepa "Arepa") (corn cakes), [aborrajados](/wiki/Aborrajado
"Aborrajado") (fried sweet plantains with cheese), [torta](/wiki/Torta
"Torta") de [choclo](/wiki/Choclo "Choclo"), [empanadas](/wiki/Empanada
"Empanada") and [almojábanas](/wiki/Almoj%C3%A1bana "Almojábana").
Representative main courses are [bandeja paisa](/wiki/Bandeja_paisa "Bandeja
paisa"), [lechona tolimense](/wiki/Lechona_tolimense "Lechona tolimense"),
[mamona](/wiki/Ternera_a_la_llanera "Ternera a la llanera"),
[tamales](/wiki/Tamales "Tamales") and fish dishes (such as [arroz de
lisa](/wiki/Arroz_de_lisa "Arroz de lisa")), especially in coastal regions
where [kibbeh](/wiki/Kibbeh "Kibbeh"), [suero](/wiki/Suero "Suero"), [costeño
cheese](/wiki/Coste%C3%B1o_cheese "Costeño cheese") and
[carimañolas](/wiki/Carima%C3%B1ola "Carimañola") are also eaten.
Representative side dishes are papas chorreadas (potatoes with cheese),
remolachas rellenas con huevo duro (beets stuffed with [hard-boiled
egg](/wiki/Hard-boiled_egg "Hard-boiled egg")) and [arroz con
coco](/wiki/Coconut_rice "Coconut rice") (coconut rice).[375][373] [Organic
food](/wiki/Organic_food "Organic food") is a current trend in big cities,
although in general across the country the fruits and veggies are very natural
and fresh.[377][378]

Representative desserts are [buñuelos](/wiki/Bu%C3%B1uelo "Buñuelo"),
[natillas](/wiki/Natilla "Natilla"), [Maria Luisa cake](/wiki/Maria_Luisa_cake
"Maria Luisa cake"), bocadillo made of guayaba ([guava
jelly](/wiki/Guava_jelly "Guava jelly")), [cocadas](/wiki/Cocadas "Cocadas")
(coconut balls), casquitos de guayaba (candied guava peels), [torta de
natas](/wiki/Torta_de_nata "Torta de nata"), [obleas](/wiki/Oblea "Oblea"),
[flan](/wiki/Flan "Flan") de [mango](/wiki/Mango "Mango"),
[roscón](/wiki/Rosc%C3%B3n "Roscón"), [milhoja](/wiki/Milhoja "Milhoja"),
[manjar blanco](/wiki/Manjar_blanco "Manjar blanco"), dulce de
[feijoa](/wiki/Feijoa "Feijoa"), dulce de [papayuela](/wiki/Mountain_papaya
"Mountain papaya"), [torta](/wiki/Torta "Torta") de mojicón, and esponjado de
[curuba](/wiki/Curuba "Curuba"). Typical sauces (salsas) are
[hogao](/wiki/Hogao "Hogao") (tomato and onion sauce) and Colombian-style
[ají](/wiki/Aj%C3%AD_\(sauce\) "Ají \(sauce\)").[375][373]

Some representative beverages are [coffee](/wiki/Coffee_production_in_Colombia
"Coffee production in Colombia") (Tinto), [champús](/wiki/Champ%C3%BAs
"Champús"), [cholado](/wiki/Cholado "Cholado"), [lulada](/wiki/Lulada
"Lulada"), [avena](/wiki/Avena_\(beverage\) "Avena \(beverage\)") colombiana,
[sugarcane](/wiki/Sugarcane "Sugarcane") juice, [aguapanela](/wiki/Aguapanela
"Aguapanela"), [aguardiente](/wiki/Aguardiente "Aguardiente"), [hot
chocolate](/wiki/Hot_chocolate "Hot chocolate") and fresh fruit juices (often
made with water or milk).[375][373]

### Sports

Main article: [Sport in Colombia](/wiki/Sport_in_Colombia "Sport in Colombia")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Nairo_Quintana%2C_Paris-
Nice_2013.JPG/220px-Nairo_Quintana%2C_Paris-
Nice_2013.JPG)](/wiki/File:Nairo_Quintana,_Paris-Nice_2013.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Nairo_Quintana,_Paris-Nice_2013.JPG "Enlarge")

[Nairo Quintana](/wiki/Nairo_Quintana "Nairo Quintana"): Colombian Champion of
the [Giro d'Italia](/wiki/Giro_d%27Italia "Giro d'Italia") and the [Vuelta a
España](/wiki/Vuelta_a_Espa%C3%B1a "Vuelta a España")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Mundial_Italia_2012.jpg/245px-
Mundial_Italia_2012.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mundial_Italia_2012.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mundial_Italia_2012.jpg "Enlarge")

Colombia is a perennial powerhouse at the [World Roller Speed Skating
Championships](/wiki/Inline_speed_skating "Inline speed skating").

[Tejo](/wiki/Tejo_\(sport\) "Tejo \(sport\)") is Colombia's national sport and
is a team sport that involves launching projectiles to hit a target.[379] But
of all sports in Colombia, [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association
football") is the most popular.
[Colombia](/wiki/Colombia_national_football_team "Colombia national football
team") was the champion of the [2001 Copa
América](/wiki/2001_Copa_Am%C3%A9rica "2001 Copa América"), in which they set
a new record of being undefeated, conceding no goals and winning each match.
Interestingly, Colombia has been awarded "[mover of the
year](/wiki/FIFA_World_Rankings#Best_Mover_of_the_Year "FIFA World Rankings")"
twice.[380]

Colombia is a hub for [roller skaters](/wiki/Inline_speed_skating "Inline
speed skating"). The national team is a perennial powerhouse at the World
Roller Speed Skating Championships.[381] Colombia has traditionally been very
good in [cycling](/wiki/Cycle_sport "Cycle sport") and a large number of
Colombian cyclists have triumphed in major competitions of cycling.[382]

Baseball is popular in the Caribbean, mainly in the cities
[Cartagena](/wiki/Cartagena,_Colombia "Cartagena, Colombia"),
[Barranquilla](/wiki/Barranquilla "Barranquilla") and [Santa
Marta](/wiki/Santa_Marta "Santa Marta"). Of those cities have come good
players like: [Orlando Cabrera](/wiki/Orlando_Cabrera "Orlando Cabrera"),
[Édgar Rentería](/wiki/%C3%89dgar_Renter%C3%ADa "Édgar Rentería")[383] who was
champion of the [World Series](/wiki/World_Series "World Series") in
[1997](/wiki/1997_World_Series "1997 World Series") and
[2010](/wiki/2010_World_Series "2010 World Series"), and others who have
played in [Major League Baseball](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball "Major League
Baseball"). Colombia was [world amateur champion](/wiki/Baseball_World_Cup
"Baseball World Cup") in 1947 and 1965.[384]

[Boxing](/wiki/Boxing "Boxing") is one of the sports that more world champions
has produced for Colombia.[385][386] [Motorsports](/wiki/Motorsport
"Motorsport") also occupies an important place in the sporting preferences of
Colombians; [Juan Pablo Montoya](/wiki/Juan_Pablo_Montoya "Juan Pablo
Montoya") is a race car driver known for winning 7 Formula One events.
Colombia also has excelled in sports such as
[BMX](/wiki/UCI_BMX_World_Championships "UCI BMX World Championships"),
[judo](/wiki/Judo "Judo"), [shooting sport](/wiki/Shooting_sport "Shooting
sport"), [taekwondo](/wiki/Taekwondo "Taekwondo"), [wrestling](/wiki/Wrestling
"Wrestling"), [high diving](/wiki/High_diving "High diving") and
[athletics](/wiki/Sport_of_athletics "Sport of athletics"), also has a long
tradition in [weightlifting](/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting "Olympic
weightlifting") and [bowling](/wiki/Bowling "Bowling").[387][388][389]

## Health

Main article: [Health care in Colombia](/wiki/Health_care_in_Colombia "Health
care in Colombia")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Instituto_del_Coraz%C3%B3n_-
_Fundaci%C3%B3n_Cardiovascular_de_Colombia.JPG/151px-
Instituto_del_Coraz%C3%B3n_-
_Fundaci%C3%B3n_Cardiovascular_de_Colombia.JPG)](/wiki/File:Instituto_del_Coraz%C3%B3n_-
_Fundaci%C3%B3n_Cardiovascular_de_Colombia.JPG)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/FVL_Clinica_Cali.JPG/186px-
FVL_Clinica_Cali.JPG)](/wiki/File:FVL_Clinica_Cali.JPG)

Colombia leads the annual ranking of the best clinics and hospitals in Latin
America.[390]

The overall [life expectancy](/wiki/Life_expectancy "Life expectancy") in
Colombia at birth is 74.8 years (71.2 years for males and 78.4 years for
females).[247] Health standards in Colombia have improved very much since the
1980s, healthcare reforms have led to the massive improvements in the
healthcare systems of the country. Although this new system has widened
population coverage by the social and health security system from 21%
(pre-1993) to 96% in 2012,[391] [health disparities](/wiki/Health_equity
"Health equity") persist.

Through [health tourism](/wiki/Medical_tourism "Medical tourism"), many people
from over the world travel from their places of residence to other countries
in search of medical treatment and the attractions in the countries visited.
Colombia is projected as one of Latin America's main destinations in terms of
health tourism due to the quality of its [health care
professionals](/wiki/Health_care_professional "Health care professional"), a
good number of institutions devoted to health, and an immense inventory of
natural and architectural sites. Cities such as Bogotá, Cali, Medellín and
Bucaramanga are the most visited in [cardiology](/wiki/Cardiology
"Cardiology") procedures, [neurology](/wiki/Neurology "Neurology"), [dental
treatments](/wiki/Dental_treatment "Dental treatment"), [stem cell
therapy](/wiki/Stem_cell_therapy "Stem cell therapy"),
[ENT](/wiki/Otorhinolaryngology "Otorhinolaryngology"),
[ophthalmology](/wiki/Ophthalmology "Ophthalmology") and [joint
replacements](/wiki/Joint_replacement "Joint replacement") because of the
quality of medical treatment.[392]

A study conducted by _[América Economía](/wiki/Am%C3%A9rica_Econom%C3%ADa
"América Economía")_ magazine ranked 21 Colombian [health care
institutions](/wiki/Health_facility "Health facility") among the top 44 in
Latin America, amounting to 48 percent of the total.[390] A [cancer
research](/wiki/Cancer_research "Cancer research") and treatment centre was
declared as a Project of National Strategic Interest.[393]

## Education

Main article: [Education in Colombia](/wiki/Education_in_Colombia "Education
in Colombia")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/UNAL-
Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG/200px-UNAL-
Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG)](/wiki/File:UNAL-
Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:UNAL-Bloque_M5-Facultad_de_Minas-Medellin2.JPG "Enlarge")

M5 building – [National University of
Colombia](/wiki/National_University_of_Colombia "National University of
Colombia"), designed by [Pedro Nel Gómez](/wiki/Pedro_Nel_G%C3%B3mez "Pedro
Nel Gómez")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Universidad_de_los_Andes_%283326108271%29.jpg/200px-
Universidad_de_los_Andes_%283326108271%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Universidad_de_los_Andes_\(3326108271\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Universidad_de_los_Andes_\(3326108271\).jpg "Enlarge")

Mario Laserna Building – [University of Los
Andes](/wiki/University_of_Los_Andes_\(Colombia\) "University of Los Andes
\(Colombia\)")

The educational experience of many Colombian children begins with attendance
at a [preschool](/wiki/Preschool "Preschool") academy until age five
(_Educación preescolar_). Basic education (_Educación básica_) is compulsory
by law.[394] It has two stages: Primary basic education (_Educación básica
primaria_) which goes from first to fifth grade – children from six to ten
years old, and Secondary basic education (_Educación básica secundaria_),
which goes from sixth to ninth grade. Basic education is followed by Middle
vocational education (_Educación media vocacional_) that comprises the tenth
and eleventh grades. It may have different vocational training modalities or
specialties (academic, technical, business, and so on.) according to the
curriculum adopted by each school.[395]

After the successful completion of all the basic and middle education years, a
[high-school diploma](/wiki/High-school_diploma "High-school diploma") is
awarded. The high-school graduate is known as a _bachiller_ , because
secondary basic school and middle education are traditionally considered
together as a unit called _bachillerato_ (sixth to eleventh grade). Students
in their final year of middle education take the [ICFES
test](/wiki/ICFES_Examination "ICFES Examination") (now renamed Saber 11) in
order to gain access to higher education (_Educación superior_). This higher
education includes undergraduate professional studies, technical,
technological and intermediate professional education, and post-graduate
studies. Technical professional institutions of Higher Education are also
opened to students holder of a qualification in Arts and Business. This
qualification is usually awarded by the
[SENA](/wiki/National_Service_of_Learning_\(Colombia\) "National Service of
Learning \(Colombia\)") after a two years [curriculum](/wiki/Curriculum
"Curriculum").[396]

_Bachilleres_ (high-school graduates) may enter into a professional
undergraduate career program offered by a university; these programs last up
to five years (or less for technical, technological and intermediate
professional education, and post-graduate studies), even as much to six to
seven years for some careers, such as medicine. In Colombia, there is not an
institution such as college; students go directly into a career program at a
university or any other educational institution to obtain a professional,
technical or technological title. Once graduated from the university, people
are granted a (professional, technical or technological) diploma and licensed
(if required) to practice the career they have chosen. For some professional
career programs, students are required to take the Saber-Pro test, in their
final year of undergraduate academic education.[395]

Public spending on education as a proportion of gross domestic product in 2015
was 4.49%. This represented 15.05% of total government expenditure. The
[primary and secondary gross enrolment ratios](/wiki/Gross_enrolment_ratio
"Gross enrolment ratio") stood at 113.56% and 98.09% respectively. [School-
life expectancy](/wiki/School-life_expectancy "School-life expectancy") was
14.42 years. A total of 94.58% of the population aged 15 and older were
recorded as literate, including 98.66% of those aged 15–24.[249]

  1. **Jump up ^** IPA transcription of "_República de Colombia_ ": [[re̞ˈpuβlikä ðe̞ ko̞ˈlõ̞mbjä]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish "Help:IPA/Spanish").
  2. **Jump up ^** Balboa is best known for being the first European to see the Pacific Ocean in 1513, which he called _Mar del Sur_ (or "Sea of the South") and would facilitate Spanish exploration and settlement of South America.
  3. **Jump up ^** A royal decree of 1713 approved the legality of [Palenque de San Basilio](/wiki/Palenque_de_San_Basilio "Palenque de San Basilio") founded by runaway slaves as a refuge in the seventeenth century. The people of San Basilio fought against slavery, thereby giving rise to the first free place in the Americas.[53] Its main leader was [Benkos Biohó](/wiki/Benkos_Bioho "Benkos Bioho"), who was born in [West Africa](/wiki/West_Africa "West Africa").[54]
  4. **Jump up ^** [Peter Claver](/wiki/Peter_Claver "Peter Claver") was a Spanish who traveled to Cartagena in 1610 and was ordained as a [Jesuit](/wiki/Jesuit "Jesuit") priest in 1616. Peter cared for the African slaves for thirty-eight years, defending the life and the [dignity](/wiki/Dignity "Dignity") of the slaves.[55][56]
  5. **Jump up ^** [Héctor Abad](/wiki/H%C3%A9ctor_Abad_G%C3%B3mez "Héctor Abad Gómez") was a prominent medical doctor, university professor, and human rights leader whose holistic vision of healthcare led him to found the Colombian National School of [Public Health](/wiki/Public_Health "Public Health"). The increasing violence and human rights abuses of the 1970s and 1980s led him to fight for social justice in his community.[106][107]
  6. **Jump up ^** [Javier de Nicoló](/wiki/Javier_de_Nicol%C3%B3 "Javier de Nicoló") was a [Salesian](/wiki/Salesian "Salesian") priest who grew up in war-torn Italy and arrived in Colombia a year after the bogotazo. He developed a program that has offered more than 40,000 young people the education and moral support they needed to become productive citizens.[108]
